Balanced start followed by a tart, warm & fruity middle.  The finish has floral characteristics.  The medium creamy body is soft and feels chalky at the finish.

Pours a milky chocolate-brown with a thin foam ring and some lace. Heavenly sweet fruit aroma - rich and inviting. Taste... wow. Sweet fruit and dark wheat, some spice in the middle, and a bit of a hoppy snap near the end, with a lingering spicy aftertaste. Carbonation is very fine - like tonic-water - with a nice creamy resolution to each sip. This is a joy to drink - many thanks to Robin for the bottle! Truly a treat, to be able to rate this after not being able to find it for so many years.

Bottle.  Pours a clear caramel color with a creamy beige head.  Nose is molasses and cloves.  Taste is very rich with nuts, caramel, molasses, and dark fruit.  Some ethanol on the palate, but very smooth.  Medium to full-bodied and a long liquorice finish.  I lked this one a lot!

Pours with a very big head - dark cloudy brown body. All the flavours are in the aroma - grain and malt, caramel, vanilla. Flavours work very well in the mouth, everything in harmony. Big bodied, delicious. The Bock part of the beer works in perfect harmony with the wheat, does not have any unpleasent alcohol burn, very smooth and easy to drink.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2007 Bottle @ Publick House, Brookline, MA (November 2006).  WOW, when I tasted this I described it as Sam Adams Winter Lager on steroids.  The beer pours a deep brown with an enticing aroma of malt and cinnamon, with some slight fruity notes as well.  Taste is largely malt and cinnamon up front, with a slight fruit and hop aftertaste.  Wonderful, outstanding beer.
UPDATED: NOV 30, 2007 Veramente piacevole, la prima weizenbock della mia carriera; gustosa, dissetante e piuttosto corposa. Bevuta da Paola a Brescia. Gli 8 gradi più beverini del mondo

Poured from a bottle into a weizen glass.  This bock poured a dark brown color with a good sized tan head that faded away slowly.  The aroma consisted of some yeast, caramel, and fruit.  The taste was much the same, with stronger banana notes coming through.  Slightly sweet and very refreshing.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with light carbonation.  An excellent beer.
very nice brown color with a huge head, sweet fruity smell, strong malty flavor, alcohol on finish, good carbonation.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2010 Muddy brown with white head. Nutty caramel malts overall - quite simple - but extremely nice.  Filling body. Light sweet. In a way unique. Deep malty & hints of yeast.
Re-rate june 2010. Had this several times. I am not to keen on the heavy wheat bocks. Fine for the style but would prefer a doppelbock any day. From 3,9 - 3,7

This beer pours dark amber with a really full head.  The aromatcis of yeast and sweet malt with spices drive into the palate.  The palate also picks up some bitter notes but still lines the flavor with some sweeter feelings of molasses and caramel.  This stuff is excellent.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2011 Yum. This ones been rocking my world lately, a super good example of the style, with all the crisp yeasty goodness of a classic weiss alongside the malty fullness of a fine German bock. Handsome looking, with a rich busy body and a decent head, with a big kick up front and a long fruity finish. Very fine.

500ml bottle. Mug. Dark brown with a big tan, foamy head. Aroma strong with notes of banana and clove. Taste was quite sweet with notes of malt, clove, spices and dark fruit. The alcohol is well hidden. Maybe a touch of bitterness as it warms. Overall a very nice beer.

Bottle - Dark red...white head, cloudy.  Cloves, sweet malt, hops.  Im not crazy about this beer.... I guess I expected something different.  It may be that I need to re-rate it some days or weeks later.  I just finished a big meal and perhaps that is interfering with my palate.

I tried this beer on July 5, 2007 after purchasing it from my local LCBO store.  It poured a dark thick brownish colour into the glass with a large loose head that dissipated quite slowly.  The aroma is a combination of malt and wheat tones. The mouthfeel is thick and creamy with hints of carbonation.  The taste is also thick with hints of malt and yeast.
My first weizenbock. Smells very intense with an alcoholic/astringent nose. Pours the color of a hefe but dark as a dopple. Tastes like bubblegum and bananas. Good beer just not my favorite.
Complex with clove and sneaky spice. Malrt , yeast, banana aroma.  Not my favorite style of wheat brew but well done.
Dark brown or amber color. Head was long lasting. Tastes of caramel, figs and some cherry. Perfect sweetness and the alcohol is noticeable. Very tasty!

Draft at Blind Tiger.  Looks like a quad - dark, caramel brown color with a thin white head.  Aroma is all malt and bananas, with a light yeast and spice component.  Flavor is similar, really malty but theres a lot of complexity there.  Nice beer.
Lots to taste in this one, the commercial description says, "cloves", not sure thats a commendation but its accurate. cloves, toffee, sweet malts and high alcohol notes...for me...its too much.

What a magnificent brew.  Unique to itself, never had anything quite like it as far as flavor balance goes.  Clove, ginger, and more clove.  Pours just like the pic here, dark deep amber.  Aroma is cloves, malts.  Flavor is cloves, malts, ginger bites, some deep sweets, but hoppy finish.  Mouthfeel was perfect for a brew like this.  Recommended for all.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2009 I agree with my last review.  This is one of the worlds finest beers and its sad that it is rated behind an avalanche of American beers where the brewing theory seems to be that more of everything is always better.

Aventinus is a special, distinctive beer. Theres the typical banana note from the wheat, and an unmissable clove aroma. What makes this beer great is the difficult to describe complexities--exotic fruits and herbs, and an unusual bitter finish. I can never quite figure out this beers secrets.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2017 Bottle. Yeast is the most dominant component of this beer. Moderate smells of soap, earth and beef with cookie for the malt and herbs for the hops. Cherry and clove are also noticable. It has a large frothy white head with excellent lacing and is fully lasting. Color is a deep, hazy brown. Taste starts moderately sweet and acidic and finishes the same with just a touch of salt. Palate is perfect for this beer, medium to full bodied, between oily and creamy with a carbonation that?s between lively and fizzy. It has a nice warm alcohol finish as well. A great Fall or Winter beer.

Pours dark mahogany with a good sized head.  Aroma is sweet with banana and other fruits.  Flavor is smooth sweet and delicious with banana and dried fruit in the foreground.  Hops are present but way in the back.  Finish is bready yeast.  This is an excellent beer and goes down way to easily.

Bottle. Pours dark amber with a fairly rich white head. Sweet nose: bananas, plums and malt. Caramel like sweetness on the palate with just a hint of hops. Really rich and oily with  mouth-coating sweetness. Too much sweet for my tastes. A good fall beer, but one is enough.

As I poured the dark brown beer into my glass, I could breathe in the sweet malts as a gentle head rose to the top of the glass. I enjoyed my first taste as it resonated with a candy-caramel taste and ended with slight rolling hops. The commercial description nails flavors that I tasted later as I finished the bottle in no time.

Bottle 500ml : pours a hazy ruby brown with a white and slightly off-white foamy head, looks like unfiltered grape juice, effervescent, sweet, fruit, wheat, faint plum and malt aromas, brown sugar and faint charred wood smoke in the background, sweet and brown sugar with fruit malt flavors that moves to a sour and dry finish, faint alcohol on the tongue, creamy head last and lasts, bread and dark bread malt flavors, small hop bite in the finish, lots of carbonation give this a nice mouth feel, mouth feel is full even with all of the fizziness, the fruity malt flavor just continues with every drink, faint spice-pepper flavor as the beer warms, really tasty wonderful beer.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2007 Beautiful ruby/brown color with boisterous foamy head.  Smells wonderful, yeasty and bready scents with subtle hints of spice, clove and bananas on the nose.  A rounded, slightly figgy taste has echoes of caramel, toffee and cloves, and culminates in a clean, crisp acidic finish. One of the best wheat beers in the world- refreshing and truly wonderful.  Cheers!

Dark amber with a big foam. Aroma: Banana, caramel, prunes, yeast, spice.
Palate: Malt, caramel, fruity, chocolate, yeast.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2007 bottle:  Thanks to Lord Beamish for this little gem.  Unlike the gastly high alcohol content Quebec beers with pics of  guys canoeing towards a waterfall, this  beer actually has flavour without being overwhelmed by its high alcohol content.  Good example of style and huge flavours of fruit, spice & yeast ala Chimay, but not for everybody.  Id rather have a flavourful pale lager or pilsner, that doesnt require such a time committment & is far more approachable.  Do we really need a beer with this much flavour, that is also this strong?  I do think the monk on the bottle looks very authoritative - maybe monks have the kind of time to drink octane like this & nurse pints of this stuff for hours on end.  I can picture myself enjoying this in winter or late fall when a football game is on the tube around 7 & I need to feel good but dont want to drink a lot of beer - 3 beers for the price of 1. But then again Id just rather have a nice ESB, ale or stout (Beamish).  This beer will taste good as it warms but be prepared to be knocked on your ass.

bottle. deep amber shade with glowing brown and orange highlights. this one pours with a HUGE fluffy head about three or more inches tall and off white. powerful aroma with lots of complex layers consisting of yeast and extremely fruity, and slightly spiced. banana, clove,  a little raisin and some apricot area ll in there. now thats wheat beer. extremely smooth palate with lots of caramel and slightly sticky. strong banana and clove flavors with a nice spicy finish with just a touch of alcohol.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2008 500ml bottle. I was a litte weary of this one at first. Pours a sludgy brown colour (similar to apple cider), with an insane head that will appear and persist regardless of your best efforts to reduce it while pouring. Initial tastes are just yeast and alcohol, and its pretty unpleasant, with a salty aspect to it. But, as it warms it definitely opens up. Suddenly more sweet aromas are apparent, plums, apricots, even a little bubble gum. The originally severe mouthfeel softens and the taste gets sweeter with a tad sour touch to it, and it ends up being enjoyable. Really nice stuff.

Poured a cloudy white, 1-finger width head with a dark amber color. High malt in nose, little caramel. Full body and carbonation with flavors of caramel, malt, grain, earth, and soft yeast on the top. High-gravity feel for the palate and brain. Good brew. One of the better wheat beers

I have had wheat beers before. None that were highly rated so when I saw this one #2 on the RateBeer.com list for the style I thought I would give it a try. Bananas and yeast on the nose. It tasted of bananas and yeast.  I cant see myself buying again but then I dont see myself as a fan of wheat beers from what I have tasted so far.

500 ml bottle: Crazy pour. Despite my best efforts, a HUGE foamy brown head took up nearly half the glass(possibly due to original bottle fermentation?) Lacing is evident. Dark brown and yummy looking. Grainy/caramel nose leads the way to a pleasant beer experience. It is much lighter tasting than the colour suggests. Lots of wheat flavour is balanced out with wonderfully balanced malty goodness. The monk guy on the bottle has the look of a man who has put his best effort into his work. This is a beer to be proud of. Very good!
Quality product. You can smell and taste the wheat. "Ruby" is the right color description. However, still fairly bland with no hop and little roasted malt aroma/flavor.

I wont stand this one up next to the Imperial stouts and IPAs or the Belgians.  For a weizen bock, its my fave so far.  22 oz. draft at Ashleys.  Brown in color (at the bar anyway) with lots of white head.  Sweet fruity aroma.  Thick, wheaty and fruity.  Not an all-night beer, but stands tall next to many other wheats and weizens.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2007 bottle.  year?   Dark amber color with a lot of head that settles into a nice layer of foam just at the top.  Starts with a very bright hop begining and a nice clove ending.  But between that there is a beautiful under layer of apricot flavors.  Didnt taste the chocolate flavors so much.  My favorite of the german wheats because of its complexity, flavor, and drinkability.  In any case a master of the genre.

500mL bottle, 2003 vintage.  Pours a beautiful, clear honey-amber color; fluffy white head with great retention and web-like lacing.  Dense, dried fruit and candy sugar aroma; hints of a creamy vanilla note.  Lively carbonation; fluffy texture.  Full, wheaty mouthfeel: dense toffee and dried red fruits; very chewy, very satisfying weizen bock; nicely textured with a dense malt core; hints of alcohol poking through.  Medium, dried fruit and sugar finish.

draft. pours a plum colored brown with a great head. spicey clove and light banana comes through  and fades into some more rich earthy caramel and slight bitterness. yeast adds a great smooth mouthfeel . alcohol flavor was there but not overpowering. did add a nice warmth to this beer.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2009 Bottled 50cl. It pours a dark ruby-brown beer with a big head. Some sediment at the bottom of the glass. Strong aroma of banana and malt. A full bodied beer with some alcohol in the taste, caramel, lots of banana. Some white pepper elements in the taste that I find unenjoyable. Cloves and hints of black chocolate with a decent sourness and sweetness. Rather strong alcohol presence in the finish (quite dry) with hints of licorice. It s not a bad beer, but I didnt enjoy it that much. I had this beer several times, even 3.3 seems too high in my opinion. Really dissapointing.

Bottle served in its very own Aventinus glass.  Pours a red raisin-brown with a tall beige head, I have to let it fade down to pour the rest.  Aroma of bananas, clove, dough, and yeast.  The flavors are clean at first, banana and clove, until I get all of that yeast in there. Then a much creamier smoother banana, toffee, chocolate full bodied from the wheat.  Tasty beer.
wonderful smell and look. felt too much like someone dropped a shot in my beer though.  such a strong liquor taste.

Pours brown with a nice tan head with some spots and lacing. Banana clove aroma with a hint of alcohol. Earthy flavor from dark malt to compliment the aroma-following taste. A bit oily and thin, but still well worth trying.

The color was caramel/amber.  The head was thin, creamy, fizzy, and off-white.  The aroma was wheat, yeast, and strong.  The flavor was wheat, yeast, earthy, and musty.  The palate was medium-bodied.  The finish was a little musty.

500ml Bottle.  Pour is murky orange brown with a giant, light tan head.  Aroma is bananas, yeast, and some dried fruit sweetness.  Taste is much bigger than expected.  Initially get the dried fruit sweetness, smoothing into bananas and cloves, and finally with a hint of wheat in the finish.  Very nice lingering aftertaste.  Even a touch of heat  (alcohol) at the end.  There is just a ton going on in this one, yet it is subtle and really well rounded.  Very nice.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2011 1) Muddy deep brown weizen capped with off-white, receding suds. Swirls with sediment against the light. Aromas to drown in- banana liqueur and clovey spice with a fusty edge of wood-tinged sourness. Overripe bananas dipped in melted toffee and dusted with clove and white pepper. Big, toffeeish malt drying out into a clipped, slightly warming finish. But the alcohol is beautifully disguised. Drinks like a seductively spicy Hefe/St Bernardus/Sour Ale hybrid. Blindfolded Id swear it was Belgian. How the Germans conjure something as headily fruity and spicy as this out of just malt, hops, yeast, wheat and water is nothing short of a marvel. The sort of beer youd name your children after.   
2) Bottle Inspire, Coventry. Just WOW. Full-on banana and clove; a mouthful of heady, sahti-like esters. Texture of milkshake. Made the Orval I had afterwards taste like flat lemonade. World class, and one of my all-time favourites. (Upgraded from 948417 to 949518).

Bottle from LCBO, courtesy of a friend. Poured a beautiful dark liquid. The nose was set off with incredible touches of cherries, grapes, malt and a floral scent. Mouthfeel had a thick, rich and velvety texture. Taste was of cloves, banana peel, caramel and spices. A wonderful beer!

Bouteille. Couleur brune-rougeâtre voilée, belle mousse compacte, qui sefface très lentement pour laisser place à un lacet traçant légèrement le verre. Arôme assez doux de malt caramel, chocolat, bananes. Goût complexe de bananes, malt caramel, torréfié, sucres, épices, alcool timide en finale. Rondeur pleine, effervescence modérée, mais créant une douceur géniale. Plus la bière réchauffe, plus les saveurs saffine et se modifient pour le mieux, le changement est hypnotisant. Cest vraiment bon. Une de mes bières favorites, et facilement disponible à la SAQ.

Brown but still translucent with a roof of bubbles that billow forth toward the top of my glass.  Enormous nose full of dates and bananas.  Some yeasty stuff in there as well.  The taste is thick with alcohol making its presence known.

Aroma of chocolate, sour cherries, alcohol, and clove. Dark brown with a nice white head. Flavor is chocolate, some spice, alcohol. Can definitley tell it is a style of bavarian wheat. Pretty full bodied. Alcohol is pronounced. Pretty carbonated as well. It is cool to get this at a bar for sure. It tastes good. I dont have to drink a ton of it, and it gets me pretty inebriated!

Poured a dark rich brown color with small head that quickly dimished.  Smelled of dark fruits, wheat, some spice.  Taste was dark fruits, big wheat presence, some residual sweetness with a nice slightly bitter finish.  Overall quite smooth and drinkable.  However, I dont think this compares to the Liverys weizen Bock.
The king of Wezenbocks.  Everytime I am at Ludwigs in down Philly I am always having a couple of these.  Great rich taste.

Rated 9/15/06:  Sturdy wheat with a nice aroma and awesome flavor. Refreshing wheaty scent, very crisp. Pour is a light amber/dark copper huge head and moderate lacing. Satisfying to the palate, with a strong alcohol finish that is exceptionally smooth. Flavor is truly remarkable. Underlying wheat presence with a nice malty sweetness. Well balanced and very drinkable. Great brew here.

Pours dark semi-opaque brown with a medium foamy head. Aroma is of heavy caramelized banana, baked bread, roasted nuts, and chocolate syrup with a musty woodiness. Flavor is the same with more of a yeasty banana presence and roasty vanilla aftertaste. Palate is full and smooth. Lots of carbonation.

Got a bottle of this on a trip to Lincoln, NE at The Still and poured it into my weizen glass. Has a very nice burgundy color with lots of visible carbonation and a rocky 2 finger tan head that reminded me of bath bubbles. Straw, wheat, nutmeg, cinnamon, caramel, toffee, vanilla, and the aroma of a bread box are all present. Taste is Sweet with nutmeg, cinnamon, wheat, banana, vanilla, and dried fruits. Aftertaste of Wheat, vanilla, banana, clove, and some other spices Im unsure of. A nice medium body, but way too much carbonation. It almost burned a little bit. Great beer! It reminded me of Christmas in a way. I expected Celebrator since the bottle says Doppelbock but was pleasantly surprised.
From a cellars sampling.  Lots of green hop on the nose of this brown beer.  Hoppy and sweet body with some apple flavors.

a must try. nice aroma and looks good in the glass. nice experience in the taste with a cocoa caramel stage filtering over and under a delightful anisette sweet banana clove layer that works under the watchful eye of a raisin and licorice overseer.sourness makes you want to hit the yeasty marvel again.

B$6.  Banana aroma.  Im not sure if I like banana aroma yet.  Underlying yeasty aroma after sitting a while.  Medium lacing.  Medium reddish brown color.  The banana aroma is present in taste as well.
Sadly I cant recall anything about this beer, which means Ill have to buy it again, but I do remember the fact that I really enjoyed it and found it to be a fantastic surprise.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2008 Wow, when you really enjoy a beer that you arent expecting to enjoy because of its style, that shows you it is a good beer. I loved this beer even though I am not a fan of Bocks, and I would defnitely grab this up again! Very complex, very dark tasting, though it only pours tan brown. Saturated with flavors.
Amber/copper, witha a light brown head. Aroma is caramel, malt fruit, and spices. Flavor is caramel, spices, fruit, and banana. A real treat.

Pours a cloudy root beer brown with a large, frothy, tan head. A complex aroma of many scents, I detected a heavy caramel followed by plum, cloves and a light alcohol note. Oddly, but pleasantly, it was all tied together with a strong bubble gum scent. Mouthfeel was full, creamy and perfectly effervescent. The flavor is amazing. A sweet, creamy plum up front, with caramel, cloves and banana at the finish. A slight wheat note can be detected at the end but is quickly overridden by the malts and light alcohol upon exhale. A very sweet and indulgent brew. I will definitely be sharing this one with my friends.

Bottle. This is one fantastic smelling beer. Complex aroma of dark fruit, raisins mostly and some plum, earth notes, and a honey sweetness infused with them, fantastic. Flavor fell short though some of the dark fruit coming through but the sweetness had dissapeared during the way. Palate was very pleasant and easily drinkable.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2010 Muddy brown color, with an enormously thick head. Be careful pouring this one. Apple, lemon, cheese aroma. Tastes of raisins and yeast, with no detectablle hops. Scotch whiskey on the palate. I made a batch of Kvass once that tasted exactly like this. Either Im great at making kvass, or this beer is overrated. 5/13/2007 2/1/3/2/5 1.3

Re-rate: Babyfood banana and clove aroma. Hazy brown, thick tan head. Bready banana, but not banana bread, flavor. Alcohol noticeable, but only slightly detracting. Good balance, but not spectacular in any aspect. Either this was much better this time around, or I have a better appreciation of the style I still say it is overrated, but then again I probably still have much to learn.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2008 Strong, sweet aroma followed by complex flavors make this a first-class beer. The appealing pour is dark brown to the point of ruby with a big white head that diminishes. The nose is fruity (banana, plum, raisin, pear),  sweet (caramel), grainy (wheat), slightly spicy (clove) and slightly yeasty (dough, sweat). Flavor is heavily sweet and lightly bitter at the end. Moderately acidic. A medium body is sticky on the palate. Long, warming finish.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2007 Bottle. Dark brown with ruby highlights and huge head. Aroma is first metallic-spicy hop; after head settles down is chocolate-spiced malt. Taste is malty with delicious esters - chocolate covered fruit, slight bubblegum. Mouthfeel is medium body with a nice carbonation tingle.

Pours deep amber with moderate off-white that diminishes to 1/4 inch film.  Aroma is spicy banana, cloves, caramel, and ripe fruit.  Mouthfeel is moderate and fizzy.  Taste still has that banana but not as much as the aroma would indicate.  There is prominent spice with nice sweet ripe fruit throughout.  Finish is tangy and spicy.  Very good stuff.
Pours a dark, ruby color with a long lasting flury white head. Sweet on the nose with a little fig. Rasins, dates, fig, and sweet malt on the palate with a lingering finish.

Another of my recently found sampling notes that dont contain any comments. Damn my laziness!

At least now I have confirmed that Ive had it and it seems I really liked it.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2009 Hazy brown pour with a fluffy off white head and spotty lace.  Sweet malty aroma with notable hints of spice, dark fruits, and caramel.  Flavor definitely follow suite.  Alcohol is noticeable on the finish, however its not too offensive.

Bottle. 5-3-07  This is the highest rated beer available in Arkansas, so I was hesitant to try it.  Didnt want to get my hopes up.  My buddy and I pulled ours out of the fridge and held them for a moment to let them warm.  They poured a deep red-brown with a nice puffy head.  As this dissipates, and the flavors waft from the glass, my nose perks up.  Toffee, caramel, figs and huge esters pop out immediately.  The flavor is rich and luxurious.  It has the softness and drinkability of a traditional german hefeweizen, the rich malt character of a delicious dopplebock, and the intense estery aroma of a belgain tripel or summer siason.  We stood inside his garage, sheltered from the spring rain that dotted softly outside  and raised our glasses to a friend as quiet darkness settled in around us.

Bottle. Caramel-brown color. Nice, fluffy off-white head that lasts. Notes of caramel and brown sugar in the aroma along with the hint of bubblegum. Very good mouth feel. Tastes of roasted malt and brown sugar. Slightly sweet, almost fruity flavor. Cherries maybe?
This is my first crack at a weizenbock and it is very good.

Strong scent, slightly sweet malts, fruit, banana.  Golden orange in colour, white head.  Sharp and sweet in taste, complex, fruity and spicy.  Nutmeg, banana, malty.  The alcohol content is pretty obvious sadly.  This brewery can certainly hide it (see the Eisbock - which I vastely prefer).  Ah well, still quite nice and drinkable.

bottle . . pours deep dark cloudy brown with a thick light head . . aroma is raisins, dried apricots, brown sugar, some cherry, spices and sweet . . taste is cherry, sweet, raisin, NICE . . cherry aftertaste . . awsome beer

Aroma is very yeasty and wheaty with hints of fruit.  Pours amber/light brown with foamy head that diminishes to a thin film.  Initial flavor is mostly yeast/wheat, finishes with light fruit taste with some bitterness.  Overall not my style, but not altogether bad.

Tasted this one a few years back, and i do remember it as good, but this exceeds my expectations. Aroma is so mild and sweet, yet so complex. Lots of easters, spices including cloves, cherries and vanilla. Flavor of honey and port whine, with a palate that tickels your gums in a really plesant way, warming and sleightly bitter finish

500ml bottle, $3.69.  Aroma is heavy malt with toasty, molasses, cloves, and smoke notes.  Average sized, fully diminishing, white head that left no lace.  Medium brown body with an average amount of large particles.  Flavor is lightly sweet and sour with a short finish.  Palate is watery, light, and lively.  A very good German wheat beer.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Stockholm, 20 April 2007) Dark brown colour, cloudy, with huge beige head. Fruity, yeasty, estery and spicy nose with notes of dried fruit, raisins and chocolate. Fruity and yeasty taste with dried fruit (raisins, figs, prunes), chocolate and spices (clove). Full bodied, sweetish and slightly vinous. Complex and very tasty.
Pours hazy dark redish brown with tall head. Aroma is sweet, fruity (banana), wheat. Full body. Taste is wheat, sweet, malty, grapefruits. Warming alcohol in the end. Fantastic weissbier
Cloudy amber with a big white head. Banana and bubblegum dominates the flavour. Sweet with a slightly dry finish, and a hint of roast flavour.

Bottle at Schneider in Munich. One of my favourites right here, all the more so in the relaxed surroundings of the Schneider pub near Marianplatz. Beguiling aroma and pallate, hides the alcohol like no other beer ive had. Excellent.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2007 500ml bottle. pours a murky dark amber brownish colour with a thick fluffy head. aromas of banana, caramel, cloves and spices. the taste is great, fruit, banana, malts and a nice spicy finish. a smooth slightly creamy texture with a good carbonation. one of my new favorites.

Cold 500ml bottle:  Pours a cloudy amber color with a small persistent foamy ivory head.  Aroma is of cherries, nice yeast, rich malts and caramel. Taste is of rich malts, nice yeast, cherries/fruit, subtle hops, and caramel.  Medium to full bodied and smooth with fine carbonation.  Ending is of malts and caramel with a very slight alcohol burn.
Bottle.  Aroma of some sweet caramel malt, bubblegum, and spices.  Flavor is very much the same with a smooth, slightly creamy mouthfeel.  Full body with a decent aftertaste.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2007 Sweet smelling wheat.. matched by a slightly sweet taste.  Deep red/brown.. pours somewhat thick with big head.  Flavor masks higher alcohol content well.  An outstanding wheat beer.

Schneider Aventinus has to be the most flavourful, and ultimately most satisfying beer ive ever had the privilege of tasting. It is very much full bodied, with a chocolatey aroma. The sweet caramel flavour gives way to a clove-like semi-bitter finish. The dark ruby colour and thick long lasting head makes this brew very inticing just to look at, but anyone who has ever tasted it knows, as nice as it is to look at you just cant wait to get involved in its wonderful flavours!!!

ABV: 8.2      OG: 18.5

Pour is a deep copper colored body with a generous slowly disappating head.  Strong clove, banana, along with caramel malts.  Strong carbonation, and it almost overtakes the flavor.  This is good, but I think I prefer the Weizen Eisbock over this as it is more full bodied.  Even though this beast comes in at 8.2% ABV, the flavor just falls a little short.  Good, but not amazing, as I expected since the Eisbock was stunning and this actually scores a bit higher than that beer.  

I will say that after all of the yeast is poured in, the flavor is enhanced somewhat.

amazing beer served in a cool glass.  This is the german beer that I compare all others to.  The aroma is great and full of banana and spices.  The flavors are fruit, clove, and hops in the finish.  very nice

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2009 I first had this beer from the LCBO in late 90s, but it tasted even better on tap in Munich! It pours a deep auburn colour with a huge foamy head with lots of floral yeasty aroma. The flavour is complex, with notes of wine, cherries and nutty malts. Is quite dry with a nice bitter finish. Tastes even better in it uniqued shaped glass.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2008 Pours a interesting unclear dark red brown with a thick foamy head. Strong scents of banana cream pie are first noticable, but after the beer settles the aroma becomes slightly more yeasty with notes of malts, anise and fennel. The flavor has strong notes of banana, and malts, with some spicey anise notes in the finish. The palat, is well carbonated, and pleasantly creamy. 
There is depth in about every aspect of this beer, from the aroma, to the flavor to the palat, top notch.
Rich aroma, dark amber color.  Smooth taste, alcohol well hidden.  Malty flavor with hint of banana and dark fruit.  Excellent!

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2008 Had today on tap at Map Room in Chicago, and was served in the correct glass (as shown in sample photo).  Really went down easy-- hid the alcohol well.  Rich and malty like a dopplebock, but with the underlying wheat flavors.  A real treat on a cold, windy day in Chicago.

Now that I like wheat beers I can truly appreciate a good weizen bock. Pour was a hazy light brown with no head. Aroma was all wheat and yeast. The taste was a classic hefe weizen with a taste of.....raspberries? I know but thats what it tastes like. Good stuff
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: What a tasty beer.  Its smooth yet flavorful and has a great finish.  I drank it out of a stein so I cant say much on the appearance.  Ive had it a few times but never rated it.   A world class beer.
One of my perennial favourites.  A rich mouthfeel, always moreish, and a great one to finish a night on.

500 mL bottle.  Pours a cloudy brown.  Strong banana aroma, with a bit of a floral yeasty aroma as well.  Taste is quite sharp at first taste, but alcohol taste quickly dissipates into a sweet fruity flavour which lingers nicely for a few seconds.  Overall, a very interesting beer that becomes more enjoyable as you drink it
aroma carried banana, pretty dominant head. this was a pretty good beer, not a bad bock but apparently kind of overrated on here.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2008 Cloudy brown appearance with long white head. Aroma of wheat, caramel malt. Flavor is similar with banana, cherries. Nice bitter finish. Good but somewhat overrated.

Rerate after tap in Munich. Creamy wheat feel with great fruity chocolate taste. Really hit the spot and looked incredible in the proper glassware.

Muddy chesnut brown coloured beer with beautiful white-beige head. The beer is leaving a nice lacing and the faom is covering the beer till the end. Aroma is not really powerfull but it leaves lots of fine impressions cereals, nuts, brown bread, wild rice, and fresh cut wood. The aroma is fine and delicate. Taste is smooth and quite dry for a 8.2%. Again a very elegant mouthfeel, with a slight detectable fruityness and fine malts, nuts, forrest soil, even some touches of baked shitake muchrooms deglaced with a dach of marsala wine. One of the most eazy drinking brown beers that high in alc that i ever had. Great beer, great taste, dilicate and caracterfull aroma and soft afthertaste.

Tap @ The Wharf - Aalborg. Very fresh and aroma with lots phenols and esters. Hazy brownish colour and a orangy thick head. Very full taste with lost of sweetness and a good balance between the phenols and esters.  Above averages for style -  15B maybe 15C

pours clear amber orange with a nice big fluffy white head. great banana aroma....very fresh and ripe....with some clove and caramel undertones. sweet banana fosters flavor with a nice touch of spicy black pepper and clove. spicy black pepper clove finish with nice sweet caramel undertones. medium full body with nice creamy lively carbonation. very nice.

nice dark copper color with carmel thick head.  carmel and wheat and clove aroma with some wheat, clove, carmel malt, and sour yellow cherries.  some bitterness in the aftertaste but overall i enjoyed this one.

Pours a very dark amber with a small head with tiny fizzy bubbles.  The smell was carmel and malt.  When I tasted this wiezen bock, I detected a slight hint of cherries, carmel and malt.  There was some bitterness in the aftertaste.  The finish was lasting and sour.  This is one of the best German beers I have ever tasted.

This had a small dissipating head,contrary to the commercial description.Color was red-amber.Aroma was of malts and hops.The palate was above average.It tasted of over ripe cherries,caramel ,and champagne.Nice body.Finishes dry and slightly bitter.Good beer.Somewhat complex.Buy it!!

Bottle. Sweet malt nose. Some caramel, some light cherry notes. Darker sweet aromas towards the back, and a touch of smoke. Very dark, very thick brownish read witha touch of foam around the edge. Very sharp palate, overcarbonated and unbalanced. Flavor is very sweet, cherries, a very light touch of caramel, some plums and figs. Very nice overall, just slightly too sharp on the tongue, which doesnt sit well. Nonetheless, a damn good beer.
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2007 Bottle.Large off-white head.Cloudy,dark amber.Clove,apple,pear aroma.Lightly sweet fruit flavors with a slight bitterness.Not too heavy.Very good.

Ruby colour. Big head. this is close to perfection! I´ve never tasted a weizen bock like this! So much power, aroma and still pleasant mouthfeel. Í love the finish with blackberry taste.  Great beer for sure.
Sweet teasing wheat aroma, followed by a truly great complex malty palate. Spices and cloves, some fruit. The alcohol is there but it pulls it off. Great stuff.

Great beer! Lots of blackberry, wheat, malty, zesty with bright notes. Satisfying. Nice head. Great dark wood color. Nice clean finish. Having this from a bottle at Bodega Brew Pub downtown La Crosse.

[204-20070209] 500mL. Strong fruity banana aroma. Clear, dark brown body with a huge off-white foamy head. Very banana fruit flavour with sweet malted tones. Medium body. Very nice togetherness, best to share and well-paired with pork roast. (Go banan--I mean, birthday!)

Bottle... Poured a very hazy brown with a thick white head that lasted and evolved into a nice settlement on the surface of the beer.  Strong malty and caramel aroma. Mild palate with strong flavors of yeast, malt, caramel, leafy spices like clove or tea and a really awesome bitter/sour finish.  This is one of my new favorites from Germany. I may end up purchasing this one again.
Bottle.  Pours cloudy and tark, taste is sweet.  Its scheider weisse dark gothic friend.
The best way to describe this is Schneider from One Day at a Time. I could see this bottle wearing a tool belt and having a bad 70s mustache.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2007 Dark cloudy copper/brown with a large, dense head and good lacing. Aroma of cookies, cloves, cinnamon, caramel, brown sugar, but also dark fruit like cherry, raisins and figs. Complex. Smooth and rounded taste, quite sweet with some citric sourness in the background along with some slight hoppiness and a long malty finish (very bready). Medium/thick mouthfeel, medium carbonation. Has the refreshing citric sourness & drinkability of a hefeweizen, but also the dark sweet bready malt of a doppelbock.
Pours with a hazy brown color with a small head that lasts a good while. Has aroma of carmel and malt. Has a taste of malts and maybe a bit of banana.  Excellent flavor, recommended!
Pours carmel brown with a huge foamy head. Aroma of cloves, fruit, banana. Tastes sweet, yeasty, very soft, a touch os spice. This is an outstaniding beer.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2007 This beer does so much for the taste buds and it is one of the worlds truly outstanding beers. Page 416 of Michael Jacksons Great Beer Guide and only 258 of his 500 Classic Brews to go.

Bottle. Hazy amber colour with a huge off-white head. Initially an aroma of bananas. After a while the smell is more spicy with raspberries. Flavour is spicy but actually quite weak for an 8% beer. Soft mouthfeel and a short finish.

Beautiful! From the bottle. Very deep amber color, which varies within the glass. Thick, lasting head. Fruity, sweet smell--which is in contrast to the somewhat sour taste. I detected a hint of raspberry--but without the tartness. Does anybody taste nectarines? Easy, full bodied bock. Metallic aftertaste. Complex and satisfying.
UPDATED: MAR 9, 2007 Poured from the bottle - Dark brown with "dirty-white" head.  Malty aroma and taste with some cloves in there as well.  It finished very well.  This is a very good beer.
Bottled. Hazy brown in colour. Bubbly white head. The aroma is malty, wheaty with coriander. The flavour is complex. Wheat, koriander, caramel, there is a malty and dry aftertaste.
Not so much thick as dense.  Nice sweet maltiness.  Its a bit like a piece of liquid pumpernickel with hints of dates.

1pint bottle. pours mahogony with small off white head. a real nice color. nose is pretty strange, lots of clove with undertones of mint. flavor has some strange sweet dark fruits with mint and cloves, some biscuit, plums, and stale flavor too. body is pretty weak and carbination is fizzy. no alcohol noticed. ill have to re-rate this someday cuz this seems pretty overrated to me.
Bottle from the Flying Saucer in Ft. Worth. Pours brown with a thick head. Aroma is sweet and taste is smooth and delicious.

Bottle. Nice dark brownish colour with a light brown bubbly head. Aroma of roasted malts, yeast, some sweetness and alcohol. Great bustling mouthfeel! The flavour is quite malty, fruity (raisins and figs) and bit spiced (clover) with the alcohol again appearing as a positive input. Long lasting afertaste with some acidic touch on the tongue. A very nice warming DOUBLE wiezenbock from Upper Bavaria. A truly great beer.
Great appearance. Makes me thirsty just looking at it.  Spicy, fruity, wheaty, delicious aroma.  Wonderful clove/citrus flavor that stays with you.  Great beer, enjoyed every sip.
This is a beer to be savored, it is very complex. The flavor sits on the tongue long after it is gone.  The higher alcohol is nice too....wow...
16.9oz bottle pours a dark brown with a shade of purple. It also had a thick light tan head. This was a fuckin tasty beer that I will probably buy again.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2008 dark brown, malty dark fruit nose with a lovely malty flavour with a liquorish finish ....  Tk2 bottle at home ... Dark copper brown ... big short lived foamy head ... yeasty bready deep fruit nose ... slightly sweet bready  roast malts and dark vine fruits... a hint of bubble gum banana ... reasonably spiced

Bottle. What a Weizen Bock, wow cant wait to sink my teeth into this one again. Head was large and light frothy. Color was brown with clear sparkling body. Aroma was really nice and complex with notes of toffee, banana, wheat, fruit, caramel, grain. Full boded with a average carbonation. Texture has some dryness and light alcohol. Flavor was mostly sweet, but light notes of bitterness are also present. Nice sweet finish. Top of the class so far, excellent experience.

An excellent ale. Combination of a brown ale and a hefeweizen. Flavors are very strong with a heavy wheat base. Aroma is mildly sweet. Appearance is light brown with a thick head. A wonderful malty flavor with rich toasted accents.

This pours a deep auburn with a small head that dissipates quickly.  Delightful aroma of bananas and raisins.  Lightly carbonated and creamy mouth feel.  Refreshing fruity flavors that include banana, plum, cherry, with hints of chocolate and caramel. It is well balnced and not too sweet.  I highly recommend this beer to anyone and everyone.

[Bottle, February 2007] Pours dark murky brown. Aroma is berries and chocolate. Flavor chocolate with a bit of carmel and hints of berries. Quite complex. Mouthfeel is crisp and light. Surprising for a dark beer. Amazing stuff.

500ml bottle.  Average fizzy off-white head with the color of light brown at the top and bottom of the glass and dark brown in the middle.  Aroma is of bubble gum, banana, cloves, and some malts.  Flavor is complex; sweet maltiness with light sourness in finish (in pleasant way).  Slight alcohol flavor but not enough to damage the flavor.  This is one good beer!

5000ml - Turbulent pour releases hoppy, citrusy aromas from the toffee colored liquid.  Substantial frothy head of large bubbles lasts, leaving nice lace.  Big, beefy, thick flavor, almost oily in texture, fading to sweet, nutty finish.
slittly hazy brown with white head.Nose of gely, wheat then strong banana. Crispy and refreshing for an 8.2% . Flavor of cereal, banana, physalis. The head stays until the end...

I hate to be the dissenting voice, but I found this beer to be just a touch too sour for my palate. It was pleasant enough to drink after the initial impression and I would have probably gone back for seconds, but just too sour for me. Although I can see why it gets rave reviews.
Cloudy copper color with a huge head. Spare lacing. Aroma is cloves, bananas, wheat and sweet malts. Full bodied and sweet finishing.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2007 On tap at the Acadia Cafe.  Hazy mahagony with a hint of orange glow.  Clove and banana wheat and yeast aroma, with citrus candy.  Taste brings elements of brown sugar and clove to infuse a dark, bready body.  Simple and substantial.  Finishes subtley citrusy and sour, dry and nutty with indefinite length.  Entirely lovely.
medium to large head, pleasently subtle aroma.  smooth and refreshing.  served at a nice temperature it tastes great.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2007 Hazy brown color with very large head.  Sweet aroma that has the usual W-Bock fruit and candy, but with some fresh bread scents added in.  Taste is a pleasantly sweet grain-fruit mix, with elements of banana bread and sweet pastries.  Nice, lasting finish.  Very good - no wonder it IS the style.

Pours a murky hazy brown with a nice head.  Aromas of banana, caramel, bread, and a smokey pepper type smell.  The carbonation is medium bodied and carries the sweet toffee, banana, dark fruit, clove and biscuity flavor through to a lasting earthy finish.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: The pour is awesome. Muddy brown that forms into a nice sized tan head that hangs around. The smell is spicy, fruity, and more fruit. Taste is very good, not sure how to describe it in detail, but very good. A little fizzy in the mouthfeel, but very drinkable.

Brown bottle from Florians.  Hazy/murky brown body with a couple inches of more of light tan amazingly creamy-looking head.  Pretty agressive carbonation in this one.  Banana dominates the aroma with hints of smoke, spice, citrus and yeast.  Banana, spice, and hints of smoke and nut comprise the flavor.  Fairly clean finish with just a hint of cloves on the tounge.  Creamy mouthfeel that isnt sticky or syrupy at all IMO.  Alcohol is also barely noticeable, best as I can tell.  This beer is great - like a Hef, only more complex, tasty, and satisfying.  Superb.  I can see this beer having a regular place in my DBF.

Beautiful dark ruby pour with good head retention.  Cloves and yeast register in the aroma.  The flavor is full wheat malt, somewhat sweet, with deep clove notes and little apparent alcohol.  The lack of hops detracts from the palate, but the finish is quite clean, with only a slight yeast aftertaste and slight acidity.  Overall a nicely balanced wheat bomb.

Notes of caramel, toffee, and chocolate are present.  Hop aroma is supressed, well in the background.  A slight dryness, and a bit thinner than I remember from previous bottles, from the higher alcohol content.  Dark copper with a thick off-white head.  This was a three year old bottle, so no cloudiness in the pour.  Good clarity and head retention.  Wheat malt clearly present, but well balanced with barley malt.  One of my favorites.

Very cloudy reddish brown with thick off-white foam.  Strong citrussy-wheat and caramel/brown sugar aroma.  Very sweet flavor of dark fruits and malt and wheat.  A bit too fizzy but good body and long sweet alcohol finish.
Sharp fruity aroma, dark red color.   Big frothy head.  It had a bitter flavor at first, but it got more smooth as it warmed up.  Some chocolate, with big fruity raisin or fig tones.  Liked it a lot.

Poured the 17oz. bottle into Hacker-Pschorr weiss glass.  Appears brown with a ruby glow with a yeasty cloudiness.  Lively carbonated bubbles throughout the glass.  Ester fruit aromas and cloves . Fruit esters of banana, passion fruit, and pear.  Besides that, it is accented with some malty milk chocolate and caramel.  Cloves and black pepper linger.  If you are a fan of Weiss beer then you must seek this one out.  Outstanding.

Bottle Dark brown / red pour with humongous white head. Seriously, Ive never seen head like this before, the 16.9 oz bottle filled a 32oz mug with head, and I had to stop pouring. Great clovey estery aroma witha bit of citrus. Complex flavor profile of citrus, fruits, tofee, all kinds of good stuff. Smooth and very clean finish. The only reason I wouldnt give it 0.2 more points is the head is too big.
One of the best weissbieren Ive ever had.  So smooth, but with a very light body.  Deep, rich flavors.  Phenominal wiezenbock.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2008 This is an exceptionally tasty beverage. 
Hundreds of years of weizen brewing can be tasted in every grateful sip.
You find someone whos never had a weizen bock before give them one of these to try as there is no finer example of this style on the earth.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2007 Beautiful red copper colored with a gigantic white head and some lace.  Smells very fruity and appetizing.  Creamy and smooth in the mouth and quite delicious.  I have no complaints about this beer.   Its quite cheap too considering the quality.

Poured from bottle. Cloudy, dark tan. Large head due to my rather sad pouring ability that stayed a long time! The aroma was sweet, toffee like. The taste was magnificent! Lots of flavor...Thick, sweet, plums, toffee, malty, grapes...A little bit of everything with a very sharp finish...Cant identify what gives it the sharpness though, but I sure like this beer!!

Hugely aromatic doppelbock, pours dark and thick wiht a lacy head. Malt dominates, but the other flavors make this a unique experience. I may be irreverent, but maybe im just uneducated when it comes to beer. So here it goes... it tasted like root beer. Lots of cloves, cinamonn, spice, maybe incense?  It was unique experience.

Cloudy light brownish color, topped by a huge, cream colored head of foam. You can hear this beer, the pour is so fizzy and effervescent. Head dies down after a bit to just a thin cap. No lacing to speak of. Bready yeast in the aroma while the foam is still churning, then a plumy sweet wheat after that.

Very malty flavor - wheat, chocolate, toffee, and some kind of fruity raisin bread. Delicious. Finishes a bit less sweet and mildly spicy. Very smooth, nearly full bodied. An herbal alcohol in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2010 Bottle (50 cl) from Systembolaget. Hazy dark red/brown, with an off white head that disappears slowly. Nice malt body with dried fruits, bananas, yeast and some spiciness. Sweetness and alcohol well balanced. A very nice and special beer.
Very effervescent (sp?).  Starts nice and fruity, with a very lively mouthfeel, finishes with some hops and the bit of tart fruit dies down.  Highly enjoyable.

Had it last night at chef klaus steak and seafood.  Real good.  Not what I expected but I am happy I got it.  poured like the picture.  Tasted refreshing and balanced.  Quality but maybe too fresh, needed to be  bottle fermented longer.

An excellent doppel bock.  It pours a dark cloudy brown color with a thin frothy head. Smells mostly of fuirt and malt with a hint of spice.  Initially tastes sweet with a delicate fruit taste and a hint of spice, afterwards it finishes slightly sour with a somewhat hoppy aftertaste.  Overall, highly recommended and a very excellent beer.

One of my favorite germans, it did not disappoint again.  Pours a light brown or dark amber with a stable tan head.  Smells of banana, malts, and light clove.  Tastes are similar to the smells.  Get a lot of sweet malts, banana, a little nutmeg in there as well.  The finish has hints of chocolate and a nice little bitterness as well.  This along with the Ayinger Celebrator are probably my two favorite German bocks.

Dark, rich and sweet. The wheat base to the bock gives it a tall, white rockey head and removed all astringency from the mouthfeel. Aromas of cloves and very, very slight banana and vanilla aspects. The malty bock backbone and lager fermentation suppress most of the yeasty/bready fresh aspects and give it some legs in the bottle.

Hoo boy! Doesnt get much better. Aside from aroma the only reason I didnt  give it perfect scores is I want to leave myself somewhere to go if I find one I enjoy more! Big fan of the Schneider Original but this just beats it. Picked this up while on holiday interstate - cant find it locally anymore  bugger......

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2007 I really really dont like weisses, but this one is actually quite ok. One of the most beautiful looking beers I know, huge foamy head and nice ruby brown color. Looks very appetizing. Raisins, leather, a little tar, some bananas (which I dont like). Filling mouthfeel, with almost the feel of a bottle conditioned belgian beer. This would be a winner, if there wasnt the melon/banana yackiness.. Rerate: After the first rating, Ive grown a certain liking to this beer. Its certainly one of the best brews available in its amazing complexity and appeal. A true gem.

Bottle: dark brown pour with an unusually champagne-esque head that quite audibly pops and hisses, perhaps an over carbonated bottle? the flavor and mouth feel though was fantastic with hints of bananas and dates. very palatable and pleasurable finish. highly recommended.

Bottle: Hazy reddish brown pour with an off white head. Aroma, burnt wheat, caramel, yeast, some spices. Flavor, dark fruits, spice, yeast, some roasted notes, and a hint of chocolate, wheat. Really nice brew.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a short tan head. Aroma is full of malt with wood, clove, banana, yeast, spice, and dark fruit. Flavor is dark malts with dark fruits, spice, clove, and wheat. The flavor is quite remarkable. Very smooth and easy to drink, leaves a very nice aftertaste, no alcohol burn. A wonderful beer!

15-Dec-06	500ml Bottle in Munich.	Estery, bananas, cloves, Malty. .. 	Dk Brown, cloudy.  Tan head. ..	Sweet & Malty with a tang from the yeast. ..	Smooth, although some fizz gets in the way. ..	An incredibly yummy dark wheat beer.  Great stuff.  an especially great deal at .95 euros in Munich.  Sick!

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2009 bIn short: /bA very aromatic Weizen bock.  Flowers, fruits and alcohol in this very good carbonated cocktail drink.br
bHow: /bBottle 500ml, too many times, various agesbr
bThe look: /b Almost clear brown-purple body topped by a very small beige head.br
bIn long: /b Aroma of woody malt, cloves, mint, lavender and camomile.  The nose is very aromatic with cute flowers (tulips, orchids, etc.) along with mint and why not some camomile.  Taste of watered-down-rhum, red grapes, some mint, flower petals.  Medium body, medium carbonation.  Alcohol is somewhat apparent but not distracting.  Although this is supposedly a very stable beer I often seem to get different experiences with it.  Although it could just be my bad memory.  I think Im supposed to have a bad memory but I dont remember.

First German beer in a while.  Poured a dark ruby-brown; Aroma is of bubblegum-yeast, clove, pit/dark fruit. Flavor; really light on the palate; wheat-bubblegum, malt, spice.  Light after taste.  Didnt pick up a sour impression at the end.  Was really flavorful and easy drinking; normally dont go hand and hand with me.

A memorable night in Manchester - my first night in England - hit its best note as I sipped on this revelation of a brew in the Castlefield district, talking football and politics with a rail-line worker from Birmingham.  But, trust me, its not just sentimentality that makes this one a complete knockout.  Pours a  ruddy brown with a massive white head - made even that much more beautiful because it was in that proper piece of glassware you all see to the left.  Head fades but never entirely, maybe a half-inch at its lowest point.  The nose is such an explosion of aromas:  funky wheat notes like tart citric acid, plums and berries, strong and nearly abrasive caramel, dark malt balance touched off by just a hint of spice.  On the tongue, spice and dark malt intertwine themselves with a veritable cornucopia from the fruit spectrum...bananas, dark stone fruits, apples.  Everything finishes with another reminder that what were drinking here is brewed with wheat, in that slightly funky, slightly sour after that is eminently hard to place.  Full and rich in the mouth while retaining loads of carbonated integrity.  Quite possibly the first beer ever that, when I order it up again (and I will), it will undoubtedly transport me back to that night in Manchester, completely alone but completely content, wandering the streets in some kind of half-jet-lag-half-amazed stupor.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2009 Pours a cloudy dark brown with a thick two finger head that slowly settles to a solid cap that never entirely fades, leaving behind a thin tattered lace.

Smell; lots of wheat and lemons, some hints of bananas. Theres sweet caramel, bread and dark malts. The mix of wheat beer and dopplebock aromas go together better than I thought they would.

Taste; lemons, bananas and cloves are all present, along with a definite wheat profile. The sweet malts, caramel and dark fruits make their presence known on the back end. This is a great combination a wheat and dopplebock flavors. Mouthfeel is medium to full, and so drinkable I have to make myself slow down a bit with the big abv.

I will definitely be revisiting this one in the near future.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Pours with a very big head - dark cloudy brown body. All the flavours are in the aroma - grain and malt, caramel, vanilla. Flavours work very well in the mouth, everything in harmony. Big bodied, delicious. The Bock part of the beer works in perfect harmony with the wheat, does not have any unpleasent alcohol burn, very smooth and easy to drink. Highly recomended.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2007 Behold, the tastes of the Teutonic forest - the very same one that devoured Romes persistent legionnaires, and the essence of the Schneider Aventinus.  A lot of this beer smacks of deciduous deliciousness, brought on by a naturally gentle mouth feel and an abundant collection of subtle but poignant flavors.  This is entirely different from the Aventinus Wiezen Eisbock, though they both may look alike.  Both don purple and gold, and both have Wiezen bock Eisenfivenfluerhauven printed about 28 times on the bottle, but this is a beer entirely on its own.  The head is very thick but very flat, like a clean cut tree stump, sitting about as still as possible, and receding with a grumble of disfavor.  The body is darker, with shades of red to compose a rich mahogany color, transporting me to a long lost English library of vibrant warmth and cozy trappings.  From the first sniff I can tell this is going to be a hard beer to review.  The nose articulates, but softly and almost inaudibly.  Hints of apple, cheese, oak and butternut squash barely prod the olfactory nerve endings.  It takes a lot of effort, but it is a perfume well worth it.  A dab behind the ears might be the perfect scent for an evening down at the country club.  The flavors are similarly delicate, and must be tread upon lightly to keep the atmosphere intact.  Beyond the quiet whispers of the beers mouth feel, there lie some soft and mild almonds, chestnuts and hazelnuts to provide some simultaneous meatiness and woodiness.  These are squared away with a light, soft goats cheese to balance one soft flavor with another.  The taste then transforms to a light woody tone, dropping the assorted nuts and shifting to full fledged oak.  Some hops frazzle the preceding delicate tones, but helps to whip up a full and satisfying foaminess as a backdrop to the composite taste.  The bubbly mouth feel is omnipresent, but caressing and embracing like a Kashmir sweater.  The aftertaste is even more comfortable, keeping a token scrap of oak and hops to lick on like a refined and genteel gobstopper.  Noticeably lacking in this description is any kind of fructose, glucose, sucrose or galactose, and thats because there really isnt any.  The only sugar I do pick up, and only when I direct my attention to it, is a smattering of clumped dark brown sugar.  I also noted the absence of any fruits, usually finding plum, apple or banana in a mixture like this.  No colorful sweets from nature this time around.  Only the dry and earthy concoction that makes this so well suited for a feast of the forest.  I cant help but think of my Middle School obsession with the Red Wall series and the foods they described.  This would have fit in nicely.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2007 (Bottle) Pours clear nutty brown with a big white head. Caramel in the nose with banana and tones of smoked wood. A bit sourish but also vanilla, cloves, light green herbs and some toffee. Maybe a touch of allmond paste. Spicy pepperyness in flavour playing well with the  carbonation. Pretty smooth mouthfeel and a sourish finish with notes of chocolate and sweet caramell. Medium to big body.

16.9 oz bottle.  Root beer brown color, lots of carbonation, big fluffy head that snap crackled popped on the way down.  Aroma is of clove, wheat, taste is of spice, alcohol, raisin.  Finishes light and bitter spreading all over the tongue.  Awesome.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2008 500ml bottle purchased from LCBO in Toronto.  Pours a slightly cloudy brown with a fair amount of carbonation.  Very nice wheaty aroma.  Taste is rich, complex and lovely and full of wheat and malt and a bit of spice.  Great lingering aftertaste.  Im not one that is able to pick out a bunch of distinct tastes within the beer, so I wont even try... All I know is that this beer is wonderful!
lots of ester and malt with the typical banana. very nice tatse, you can really tell the flavours have been augmented. HUGE dark frothy head. excellen weizen, one of the best out there.

.5 L bottle.  Poured a murky brown with a big light beige head, lots of carbonation.  Sweet, estery aroma with some clove as well.  This tasted better when it was cold.  Fruity and then some caramel in the finish, but as it warmed up it turned into something pretty undrinkable.  Sour flavors trying to intermingle with the wheaty, fruity characteristics of the beer didnt appeal to me at all.  I didnt think this was particularly special.

500 ml...into glass...beautiful cloudy brown color with red highlights...malted clove aroma..thick head that lingers for a nice time...nice mouthfeel very full and clean...cloves are present and a little malt..finish is lingering with light carmel and a slight stickiness to the lips
Bottle.  Pours dark with a huge head - cant get it all in the glass on a single pour! In a word: Smooth. Intense bread, clove and banana aromas.  Definately one of my favorites.

On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Beautiful dark reddish brown ib color with two finger head. Dried fruits, spices, bananas, cloves. too many tastes to acknowledge. Besides Victory Moonglow its the only of this style that Ive encountered & this reigns supreme

Aventinus has a nice head and a rather brown color with a red hue. The aroma has wonderful notes of wheat, malt and fruit and the mouth feeling is smooth. The flavour is sweet and has a lot of different notes of dark, ripe fruits, banana, nuts and wheat. Its a full bodied and heavy beer with the lightness of a wheat beer. So far I havent yet met a wheat as nice as this one, its a sheer pleasure to drink it.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2008 Poured a reddish-amber with some thin white head. The aroma was filled with cloves and some banana.  The taste echoed the aromas, again with cloves  being the dominant flavor. There was a faint caramel taste as well, followed by alcohol. The finish was yeasty.  In comparison to the only other weizenbock Ive had (Moonglow), the clove aroma and taste was much more evident.  Additionally, this brew didnt transform completely like the Moonglow did when it warmed up.  Im a big fan of this one.


                      2001 paper-wrapped version, sampled 4/25/07.  The older version was a way different animal, smelling of caramel and dark fruits, somewhat brandy-ish. It kind of reminded me of some barleywines Ive had, which I thought was pretty interesting. The aged version had more of a dark fruity taste, along with a stronger caramel flavor. It was also noticeably boozier and less carbonated. My girlfriend preferred the fresh version, mainly because the older one was boozier. As for me, its tough to choose. Theyre both so different. As it ended up due to the ladys preference, I had more of the older version and I enjoyed it a lot. I suppose Id lean toward the aged version if I really really had to choose.

About a three quarter inch head that was very frothy.  I was suprised as to how murky the appearance was.  Dark bread and hay aroma with some dough and moderate yeast.  Dry tecture and a great level of carbonation.  Ive not had many of this style, but I certainly will be buying more of this.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2007 Bottle. Pours dark, cloudy brew with nice head. Aroma of bubblegum, heavy malt, yeast and spice, hint of roastiness. Very malty flavor profile, a soft wheatiness with caramel, hint of smokiness, alcohol, raisin, sugar. Very full bodied. Excellente.
UPDATED: OCT 11, 2007 Dark brown in color with giant head that lasts forever. Sweet light aroma with strong flavor. Rich malty flavor, caramel and some light fruits. Very delicious

16.9 oz. bottle, split with my dad. Classic, appetizing hefeweizen aroma, though a bit sweeter and stronger, with the familiar clove and cinnamon elements. Pours an amber/brown color with a large amount of off-white to tan head. Sparkling, clear liquid. The doppelbock flavor dominates the wheat. Aventinus tastes like a strong European lager with weisse overtones. The malt is prominent, but so, somewhat surprisingly, are the hops. The alcohol is noticeable in the flavor, but its not overpowering. Crisp, drinkable, and refreshing in the palate, but nothing out of the ordinary. Light to medium bodied.

This is a good and interesting brew, but it is underwhelming. I expected more from what is, according to the raters at this site, Germanys second best beer. It tastes literally like a mix of a good wheat beer with a good doppelbock, as if done in the glass at home or a bar rather than in the early stages at the brewery. The weisse dominates the aroma while the bock dominates the taste. I would classify this beer as a Double Weisse Bock rather than a Weizen Bock, as "weizen" to me implies an unfiltered and cloudy brew, whereas this beer is filtered and clear like a "weisse." Aventinus would make a perfect beer for the early warm days of spring, when the sun is inviting and warm but there is still a chill in the air.

Aroma of dark fruits, almost winey. Poured full of eggshell colored suds, hazy almost purple, amber. Flavor is lightly spicy, with some cherries or plums.  This bottle may have been a little old, thus, the palate seems a little thin. But otherwise, pretty remarkable.
Huge frothy head on a dark brown cloudy beer.  The aroma is raw grains.  Medium body, with a grain taste and finish.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text:
This is one brew that I have been attempting to understand for many years now.  To help me in this journey, last week I enlisted the aid of an old Professor of mine.  We attempted to discuss the inner workings of this beer over six of them and concluded the following.......
Aventinus has captured nature and chaos and combined the two in an exciting mixture that is never the same twice.  Thank you....thank you very much
Deep brown pour with lots of bubbles and a nice tan head.  Aroma of nuts, caramel and malt. Taste of caramel and brown sugar.  Great lasting finish.

Bottled - Pours slightly cloudy amber...with a bigg fuzzy head..lots of carbonation upon opening..Aroma is lots of spicy clove and sweet fruits.. Taste is sweet with lots of (fenils?) clovey.. a malty sweet ending.. great wheat bock
Dark amber colored pour with a nice medium sized head.  Had malty aroma with hints of fruit.  Had a nice malty sweet finish.  Nice.....

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2007 Bottle. Pours dark with foamy admirable head.  Wheat and grassy aroma.  Stiff taste, sedate bubble.  This is a mature beer without all the needless bells and whistles (ie. not overspiced).  Its German pure! Light for a bock in body, not in alcohol.  Another German standard showing how a beer style should be done!

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2007 500 mL bottle.  Deep brown (wouldnt quite call it "ruby" - more orange/copper), with thick beige head.  Aroma of spice, alcohol, and the old banana/clove thing.  Flavour goes through at least three distinct stages, as the alcohol enhances, rather than smothers each.  Initially you get the alcohol, which then sweetens into a bit of caramel, along with the usual wheat beer flavours.  The finish is interesting as well: it begins bitter, but gradually sweetens.  This beer sweetens significantly as it warms, but the alcohol does not become more prominent.  Incredibly smooth and full.  Excellent.

Pours like a soda with a thick, off-white head that gives away its wheatiness; fair amount of lacing.  Aromas of fruity yeast, spice with a hint of hop herbacousness.  Big flavors of wheat malt with pleasant yeast and a slight sour twang.  Full bodied, very well balanced.  Long wheaty finish with a bit of alcohol warmth; hard not to drink in gulps.  I have had this beer on a number of occasions and can say that it is one of the best beers I drink.  Truly excellent.
UPDATED: DEC 17, 2006 A misty, dark brown appearance with a hearty mouthfeel. Geat tasting with a prunish/clove flavor. Very palatable.

500ml bottle - pours a deep brown shade, with a big, rocky white head. Small red highlights at the edges of the glass. Plums, banana, clove and yeast in the nose, along with some sharp spiciness. Mouthfeel is truly wonderful and velvety, while still being heavily carbonated. Very soft. Perfect really. Flavours take what is offered by the aroma, but add in a slighty bitter and sour character that cuts through the wheat at the finish. Alcohol is well hidden, but not invisible. Actually a very simple beer really. Uncomplex, though extremely satisfying and delicious. Highly recommended.
Not sure what the big deal is here. Pours a nice syrupy brown, with aromas reminiscent of a belgian. Flavor is pleasant, though the aftertaste is not very agreeable.
gream amount of head, lotsa caremel malt character, lotsa carbonation, some bitterness, bubble gum and banana, and a little bit of wheat on the finish

An interesting, murky-brown beverage with a slight infusion of red around the edges. Spicy, wheat-beer-styled aroma with an additional hint of cocoa powder in there somewhere. It packs quite a fizz - so much that the fizz actually obfuscates some of the anticipated flavours. What is easily detectable is a nutmeg spiciness and a chocolate malt finish. Interesting and unusual.

Pours a very pretty auburn color, dark ruby. Nose is of banana-clove and alcohol. Flavor is a VERY creamy smooth velvet blanket. Sorta like a doppelbock made with wheat. But I dont like wheat. So it leaves a weird after taste for me. Im not really into it but I could see how if you like wheat beers you would love this. Great palate.

Color is a dark garnet-tinged amber-brown.  Huge light tan head that sticks around impressively well.

Potent, estery, spicy aromas with lots of fruit and a bit of smoke too.

Begins innocently enough, then overtakes the palate and especially the nasopharynx with a sledgehammer of cocoa-accented clove flavor.  Hint of alcohol is also apparent.  Significant carbonation combined with fairly full body make for a chewy mouthfeel.  Finishes impeccably smooth, making this beer tremendously drinkable despite its undeniable power.

I love the intensity of character here without a terrible amount of sweetness.  It really makes this beer satisfying and drinkable.  The only minor disappointment is that it doesnt have much in the way of complexity, although that shouldnt be surprising given the simplicity of the ingredients.
Get alot of malt and bananas in the aroma.Pours a muddy brown with a big off white head.Sweet flavors with a good amount of light fruits.Medium mouthfeel with a fruity and alcohol finish.
Very different from any beer that I have tasted before.  It has a very distinctive clove flavor.  Really enjoyed it with Gruyere cheese.
Bottle - The prettiest beer I have yet to see: A dark brownish ruby color with a thick white head.  Sweet on the palate and the high alcohol content warms the stomach.

500ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy light brown colored body under a large fizzy and foamy beige head with excellent retention.  Aroma is just bursting with banana and clove esters.  Hefty earthy wheat base with lots of yeast, light coffee, and a touch of alcohol.  Flavor is very fruity with lots of banana, cloves, yeast, some chocolate, light alcohol, and a touch of coffee.  Extremely full flavored.  Mouthfeel is thick and full bodied with soft natural carbonation that cuts through the heavy malt and wheat nicely without being distracting.  Clearly the benchmark for the style.  Stll the best after all these years.

Almost purple brown appearance with a thin head that holds but yields little lacing. Loads of carbonation bubbles continuously float up from the bottle of the glass. Large wheat smell with some alcohol and chocolate malt. Tastes are along the same lines being very sweet initially with some yeasty flavors initially and the alcohol flavor very strong in the finish. This is a great beer that I cant get enough of. Delightful.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2007 Long awaited.  Looks like cloudy apple cider.  Alittle stronger than I anticipated in the initial flavor.  Flavor is surprizingly somewhat like Penn Weizen!  Finish is a little more bitter than I would like...and it lingers.  Alcohol content stands out in the drinking.  Victory weizenbock tastes better.  Im not sure why this has such a high rating.  Figures, ...will not buy again.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 5, 2007 Pours hazy dark amber with an average light brown head.  Aroma is moderatly malty, wheat, and yeast.  Leather bananna and bubblegun.  Flavor is well balanced moderatly malty and bitter.  Finishes more on the malty side.  Bananna and clove.  Light to medium bodied, watery and softly carbonated.
Dark wheat beer. Aroma of wheat. Taste of wheat but not of the standard of Hoegarden. Wat tasted together with Westmalle dubbel and St. Feulliens christmas beer, both was light years ahead.

Poured darker than I expected a wheat to; thicker head than expected as well.  Lacing races away rather quickly.  Very nice fruity flavor; somewhat metallic and dry on the tongue.  Reminds me of Hoegaarden in after-taste and smell.  Overall, a very enjoyable drink.  One of the top wheat beers Ive tasted.  Try it; you wont be disappointed.

16.9 oz bottle - Pours dark amber with almost no head and some big floaters, though I tried to pour carefully.  It smells of yeast, caramel malt, and alcohol.  The taste is sweet and caramelly with mild alcohol presence and a hint of spice.  Some hops turns up in the finish.  Its good, but I wasnt quite as impressed with it as many have been.  Maybe Ill have to have it again sometime and reconsider.

This is a real treat..i had the chance to get this but let it slip, not this time, and it was worth the wait, pours a murky brown colour, everlasting headf ring, good lacing, now THIS IS A WHEAT, sweetness on the lips, and a beutiful bitterness. i drank it really cold and let it warm up, i suggest the same, this rocks!
Dark amber brown color with nice fizzy head.  Aroma is a bit sour but fruity.  Flavor has nice malty flavor.  Good Beer.
Pours with a red tint with a nice head. Very fruity with quite a kick. It made a believer in wheat beer.

Bottle.  I had to get into it a bit before I really appreciated it - had to work my way past the over-ripe bananna element. Pretty beer with a natural appearance.  Not overly smooth, a bit choppy, but not necessarily in a bad way.  A very different beer for me as I have not had many weizen bocks.  This will take some further inspection.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2006 Bottle. Looks sort of like a trappist beer, although it is not nearly as opaque. Aroma of cherries and citrus fruit, fairly vinous and the alcohol is very present. A big bitter adrenaline rush ends in a muted mish-mash of nuts, banana, spices, and grapes. A nice silky texture keeps this one well balanced, although it is a bit underwhelming.

Poured the color of muddy water.  A nice head with lacing that lasts.  There is spice to the nose and caramel hints.  Caramel hints with clove and fruit.  Very smooth on the palate and last on the linger.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2007 Poured a transparent, hazy, reddish, brown brew. The head is very very thick, light tan, but quickly receding. The aroma was spicy and sour. Tasted acidic, sour, spicy, and hints of banana. The palate was very nice and crisp. Went down warm (probably bc of alcohol). The alocohol actually adds more to the beer as it warms.
Bottle. The best of two worlds here... Really thick malts and a hefty bit of German weizen all rolled into one.. This will become a regular.
caramel apples, bananas, cloves and a nicely sweet finish.  not too bitter, but its there, along with some nice warmth.

It looks like an opaque cola, but of course with a much more dense and stable head. The aroma has a lot of nuances, but is not very powerful: Malts, yeast, wheat, and a little bt of raisins. Obvious yeast- and wheatflavor (sourishness), and a lot of different fruits as raisins, plums and figs. Also a light alcoholic flavor towards the aftertaste which is mainly with wheat and a good amount of bitter hops. The alcohol is a bit too obvious to give the beer the top-grade in flavor.  Good body, but not so overwhelming that it looses its wheaty character.

A very pleasing wheat beer.  I am not typically a fan of wheat beers.  Or, I do not go out of my way to try them, but Aventinus is a wheat beer I would drink all day long.  The slight caramel, full bodied nature of the beer, and the lasting bitterness that is encompassed by the other flavors make this a very, very good beer.
Awesome beer. Heavy head. Not a good pint glass pour. Wider the glass the better. A lot of bananas and spice. Great dinner beer.

500 ml bottle Opened with a pretty good hiss.  Pours a brown color with a huge light tan head.  Light lacing as the head settles.  Aroma is full of yeast and esters.  Flavor has a wide range of sweet fruit (banana) and spice.  Very little hop presence.  If I tasted this beer blind, I would have probably said it was some type of Belgium brew.  I was hoping for a little more malt.  Medium body.  A good beer.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2006 500ml bottle. Very dark huge white head. Aroma of cloves, citrus, tastes of very sweet malts cloves, and kind of roasted and not to mention wheat wheat wheat. If you love wheat beers and doppelbocks there is no other. Excellent full body beer very very superb. Tired it at three floyds.  Thanks Mike I have a new favorite.

Bottle 0,5l at The St Albans Beer Festival 29 Sep 06. Deep brown coloured. Unclear. A large tanned creamy head that lasted. Metallic wheat beer aroma with some hints of banana. Rich flavour: Fruit and roastedness. A lasting bitter finish. A good beer, but a bit too carbonated.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2006 My very first 99% beer.  I had two.  Poured dark with a long-lasting head.  Smelled of fruit and cloves.  I loved this beer.  Even as my second one got warm.  Yeast and a hint of caramel highlight the mouthfull while the alcohol gives a warming sensation.  This is a really good brew.

500ml bottle. Weizenstarkbier with flaschengärung (BB.23.05.07). Tan, creamy foam over a slightly unclear, ruby brown body. Rich wheaty aroma with notes of cloves and plums. Moderate fruity and spicy character combined with sweet malts. Warming finish with a careful yeasty touch (last drink at The St Albans Beer Festival, 29.09.2006).
