Reddish-brown pour with a small quickly fading off-white head.  Sweet caramel aroma, with clove and bannana.  Similar flavor with a dry wheat aftertaste.  Medium body.

Pours a brilliant dark brown with a thick, long-lasting white head. Clove-like aroma with flavours of spices, fruits, malt, caramel and wheat. Full-bodied with a smooth, bitter finish. A lot going on in this one. Exceptional brew!

Pours a dark golden brown with an off-white head.  A spicey caramel, dark fruit, malty aroma.  Very good flavor of spices (cloves and nutmeg), dark fruit, sweet malt, wheat, banana, etc.  Complex ale, this stuff is good.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2006 500 ml bottle served in a glass chalice. Pours a dark golden brown into the glass with a one-finger foamy whitish head that dissipated rather quickly. Very, very tantalizing and complex brew. Nose of dark malts, caramel and dried dark fruits along with vanilla and cloves. Tastes like Christmas pudding or fruitcake with the traditional weizen flavors of vanilla, clove and spices but with the added alcohol warming sensation. Delicious! I have two bottles cellared right now ready for Thanksgiving and Christmas!

I am tasting this with a friend side by side with the Flying Dog Wild Dog Weizenbock...  The Aventinus Weizen Bock is a murky chocolate brown color.  Mild carbonation with a huge foamy light head that dissapates quickly.  Lively carbonation.  Aroma is wheat, clove, plum, and banana nut.  Flavor similar to the aroma - banana nut, alcohol, and lots of fruit.  There is a lot of alcohol to this one - I can feel it evaporating through my nostils!  The mouthfeel is medium to full, but strangely fizzy.  Overall the aroma is much fruitier; the flavor is more wheaty, and the alcohol is much more pronounced than the Flying Dog Weizenbock.  I hate say it, but I think that the Flying Dog Wild Dog Weizenbock is more complex and better all around.

 500 mL bottle, $3.69 from Jungle Jims (brought by Terry).

We did a Vertical Pairing with the 2001.  The beer was ruby in color.  Pure white head.  Slight berry aroma.  All the characteristics of a DUNKELWEISS, very distinctive. Doesnt seem like a BOCK.   lots of fruit.  Berry, wheat and Mixed Berry.  Slight malt in the distance.  lots of spice: cinnamon clove nutmeg.  This one needs to be aged!
Bouteille de 500 ml. Belle couleur brune caramel légèrement brumeuse, bon collet beige. Arome de malte de caramel et dépice bien mélangé. Bon petit goût dépice sucré, aucun arrière goût dalcool.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2009 Pours hazy yellowish/brown with small tan head. Aroma mostly of wheat, bananas, spice, and a hint of alcohol. Flavor is basically the same as the aroma with a hint of chocolate. Medium bodied, finishes slightly bitter on the palate, with good carbonation.

Fruit salad in a bottle. Well, maybe not the rockmelon. Beautiful colour. The subtle apple flavours and strong berry flavours combine well with standard banana. A bit nutty as well methinks. Pretty sticky, pretty alcoholic. All around delicious.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2012 Bottle. A hazy medium to dark brown beer, with a large, frothy, mostly lasting off-white head. The aroma is moderately to heavily malty (toasted grain, roasted bread,  hint of caramel), lightly to moderately yeasty (cobwebs), withy notes of toffee, plums, dark fruits, figs. clove, banana, hint of gum. The flavor is heavily sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Medium to full body, velvety/sticky texture, lively carbonation, long finish with light to moderate bitterness, lightly alcoholic. Wow, fantastic. Hugely malty and quite complex/fruity. Only a bit sticky, but almost no alcohol feel and definately drinkable for its size.

Poured from the bottle at The Volunteers on Baker St (London), deep brown with a large rocky slightly off-white head. A strong raspberry aroma with juicy malt in the background. Malty on the palate, with stewed pip fruits and caramal towards the middle. The finish is rich and tangy.
Dark brown almost black with a creamy tan head. Sweet malt aroma with caramel . Sweet spicy caramel malt flavor with a slite bitter finish.

Wheats are not my favorite style, but the darke/stonger/more compexr the better as far as I am concerned.  This one does all three of these well and therby does well by me. ;)  Fruity, and achohol nose and taste..  Malty (wheaty?), but on the dry side. Nice head.  One of my favourite wheats.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2006 500 ml bottle - Pours a rich mahogany, with an large white head which lasts awhile.  Aroma of banana, some spice, grapes and wood varnish, though not in a bad way.  Taste predominantly of banana and citrus, followed by the wheat, with some sourness in the finish, which is also when the alcohol makes itself known.  Slightly sticky in the mouth, whether this is from th hops or something else, I dont know.  A complex and delicious beer, one that belies its high alcohol content in its easy drinkability.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2007 Pours a reddish brown. The first thing you notice is the aroma of fruit. Sweet malt flavor, easy going down. This is a good dinner brew.

Thank you Stegosaurus
Re rated after having it on draft Ludwigs

Bottle. Pours a crazy sorta purple brown with a giant creamy white head. Malty, rich rotten fruit smell of a Belgian. Flavor is really odd: grapes (those big ones you have to peel, cant think of the name now) , rotten apples, saccharine, copper, water (like the flavor of water, if that makes any sense). Really odd, but not necessarily as bad as it sounds. Man, the head stays around for ever, with really nice lacing on the side. After taste is the rotten fruit and, especially, copper. Like pennies. Mouth feel is fine, not too thin, but not as thick as the beers this is akin to. Whatever. Not ad, but feels like a poor mans Belgian.

First time I try a weizenbock. Great brown look with firm head. Delicious roasted caramel & weizen flavour with creamy and smooth end; some various fruity and nut flavour mixing in the background. Awesome!

Clear mahoganey pour. Fizzy/frothy light tan head. Aroma has prune juiced banana and slightly toasted wheat that is lightly graced by German hops. A little fizzy, but that is forgotten by the sweet, but not too sweet, prunes, banana, spices. Really good, balanced, flavorful beer.

This is an extremely balanced beer.  Aromas of Fruit Cake, a little cinnamon, cloves...  Lightly bitter, fantastic body, just the right feel to the palate, not to thick, not to  thin... like i said... very balanced!
On Tap at Flying Pie on Fairview Pours out a hazy amber with a off white head. A very nice Belg aroma and Great tast. Very sweet and fruity as well.

One bottle from BOTW.  Nice off-white head that stays well.  This beer is fun to drink! Fruity and caramel taste. A nice smoothness to it and a slight bitter lingering taste on the palate.  Very enjoyable.  Ill have again soon.  I used this beer to celebrate Erica coming in 1st in the Marcus Whitman cross country invite.  She is an 8th grader and won the JV division beating over 120 8th to 10th grade girls.
Pours thick and dark with a quickly disipatting head.  Taste is refreshing like a hefe but has the maltiness and punch of a great doppelbock. One of my favorite

ive been looking forward to this.  had it a couple years ago, but that was out of a bottle and before i knew much about beer.  homogenous, large bubbles comprise a 3/4 inch head.  rather plain.  dark brown appearance, becomes a deep cherry brown in the light.  smell is strong from afar, even when very cold.  when cold, it tastes of strong malts, somewhere between dark and light fruit.  reminds me of munich.  way closer to a weizen than a dopple.  no alcohol.  as it warmed, alcohol became extremely obvious.  maybe the cheese/crackers hurt it, but taste took a tremendous hit.  i almost feel bad giving it a 3.6, but thats where the numbers arrive.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2007 Bottle from Uto. Told by someone that this was one of the best beers in the world. He was right. Dense dark amber in colour with a fantastic thick creamy head. Looks especially good in the appropriate, extremely phallic glass. Slightly perverse appearance when combined with the overflowing white head. Aroma similar to that of red wine and fruit bread with raisin, plum and raspberry standing out. Mmmm, a tasty snack. Immediate taste of chocolate orange evolving into cinnamon with a salty-ish edge. Nice finish of raisin bread with a slight bitterness. Only fuss is the abundant carbonation.  Well balanced and brilliant!

Bottle.  Pours dark ruby/brown, with a large bubbly white head.  Aroma is a mixture of wheat malt, banana, yeast, spices, a hint of dark fruit, and a hint of bubblegum.  Flavor is sweet and malty up front, with noticeable banana and bubblegum.  Grows spicier and fuller towards the middle, with a variety of harvest spices and dark fruit.  A lingering finish with all those components accentuated by a light bitterness and just the slightest tinge of sourness.  Velvety mouthfeel.  Very good: Complex but well blended.  I rather like the doppelbock/weizen combination, and this beer pulls it off excellently.
Bottle - Thanks to Sebastian (DerDoppelbock) for trading.  Lightly hazy, brown body.  Nice aroma of flowers: hops yeast with some hints of alcohol.  Moderately bitter flavour.  Quite nice beer.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2006 Er som en dunkel weizen, bare utrolig stærk. og mere maltet/karamel agtig.

Nærmest hvidtøl smag - dog ikke så sød

Gær duften og smagen er meget tydelig.

Farven er brun grumset.

ikke lige min stil.
I like the body creamy, soft like a deep red velvet. Light bitter in the initial flavor and changes to something almost sweet.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2007 Pours a deep brown with a lively & fizzing tan head. Beautiful aroma of sweet rasiny fruity alcohol & yeast. Has a solid malt character, with fruity suggestions of plums, raisins and a slight touch of banana. Finishes with a smooth toffee like flavor. Very nice.

500 ml bottle. Huge expansive white frothy creamy head tops off a clear medium amber brown ale. Efervescent carbonation. Head stays there tilll the end. Malty, bready toast aroma backed by earthy hop spices and cloves. Very inviting. Smooth malty sweetness up front just barely balanced by hop bitterness -- to the sweet side but not cloying. Alcohol warmth in nose in mouth after swallow. Lingering clove but very clean. If you want a sharper version make sure you pour the yeast at the bottom of the bottle - for a softer version leave the last bit of beer in the bottle. Your choice but makes quite a difference.
Pleasant fruit aroma.  Mostly plums, and coriander.  Can definitely taste the wheat throughout this.  Nice color, but not nearly as ruby red as advertised.  Nice beer, but too sweet for my taste.

Hazy brown color with off white head. Strong aroma of sweet malts, wheat, prunes and dates. Lots of carbonation. Flavor of sweet fruit, sweet malts, wheat and coriander spice. The wheat flavor lingers into the finish.
nice i like. fizzy nice weisse head murky brown color. it smell like hay clove yeast malt. it taste like it smells. very sexy. i like the 8% ness i can do this again and again and agian and again
500ml bottle-pours a tan head with hazy brown color.  Aroma is dark cherry, malt.  Taste follows, sweet.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2006 500ml bottle. Im not usually a fan of wheat beers, but I think this is because I had a few bad ones and avoided them since. This beer has changed my mind completely.

After opening the bottle Im hit with the strong aroma of bananas, bubblegum, and over-ripe apples. It pours a deep reddish brown with a very thick-off white head, and the aroma just gets stronger. The flavor itself didnt have as much of the banana that the aroma seemed to be promising, instead sharing the flavor with more bubblegum, ripe fruits, cloves, and a hint of anise. The finish was smooth and oily, but not so thick that it wasnt easy to drink. The rater below me hit the nail on the head... the flavor - especially the aftertaste - was extremely reminiscent of Trois Pistoles. One of my new favorite beers. Just awesome.

Yum.   Nice mammoth head.  Very carbonated beer.  Nice reddish rust-like color.  Taste is awesome.  Very belgian like.  Reminds me of Trois Pistoles in flavor.  Yeast, banana, spice.  Some alcohol burn.  Very very good stuff.

Thick off white head dominates along with a clear dark reddish brown appearance.  Soft yeasty aroma of rising bread dough.  Yeast, tart citrus, banana, and a sweet/sour maple taste along with some alcohol in the throat.  Smooth and nice like a weizen should be, yet with interesting flavors and a kick.

absolutly wonderful-a modern classic-the warming body is laced with levels of flavour that is perfectly balanced by a great spicy edge 
the drinkability belies it 8% abv however this will catch up with you fast
this is my ideal winter warmer

500ml bottle, 8.2% a/v

Pours a cloudy ruby colour with a head which just keeps on coming. Be careful, leave alot of room for the head to expand!! The smell is very complex with notes of cherries, malt, berries and booze. The flavour is somewhat like bananas berries and spice all mixed together, and is very complex and interesting. The palate is much the same as the flavour with a beautiful lingering aftertaste. Doesnt really taste boozy at all which surprised me!

I took this beer out of my beer cellar, "beer closet" and chilled this one for a few hours.  I popped the cap and immediatley smelled the fruity smell.  With that I poured and was greated with more fruity smell and a large whitish brown head.  It quickly subsided and I let it sit for a few minutes.  My first taste was sweet with a long lasting annoying sweet taste.  I will end this review with the fact that I couldnt drink this one down in the hour I devoted to it.  Just way too sweet for me

Bottle, Strong wheat-doppelbock.  Tastes like a dunkelweizen but much stronger alcohol on the aftertaste at 8.2%.  Full of sweet notes, good clove bananna aroma and thick solid palate.   Good overall but I prefer the dunkelweizens.

Pours with a solid high slightly off color head.  Begins with a sweet fruity taste that quickly moves to a wheat crispness, and then back to a fruity aftertaste, high on banana.  A long finish on this makes it taste like a very heavy, very long hefeweizen.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Pours brown/dark amber mix depending on light with a huge off white head.  Aroma almost like a belgian strong but with the German banana.  Taste of a lot of banana with a musky caremel flavor that is really cool. Wheat and alchohol also come through.  Great mouthfeel.  Yah GRIM!!! You picked a good one this time you big stud you!!!
Pours brown with a large fluffy off-white head. Aroma of candy and fruit. Flavor is sweet sweet sweet. Very nice.

Hazy brown with a tall tan head. Fruity aromas of bananas and yeast. Sticky sweet, full bodied with a subtle clove undertone and a slight spicyness.  Roasted malts and sour dark fruit combined with a diminished alcohol presence makes this easy to drink. Remarkably dry for a beer of its weight.  Rich and rewarding.

Aventinus! First tasted this last year, but could not forget it. Its hard to appreciate if one has only tried a single bottle. There is nothing rough or crude about this drink.  Not too fruity or sweet. Nothing harsh and full of flavour. Truly delicious. A rare pleasure to drink, especially nowadays. If only I could have it every day. I would never tire of it. Make sure all the sediment goes into the glass, although Ive forgotten how to turn the bottle correctly.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2006 Draft.  Aroma: Nice toffee aroma.   Raisins, vanilla, and banana.  Very bready.  Appearance:  Light brown with dark orange highlights.  Head was white, big, and mousselike.  Nice head retention.  Flavor:  Lots of sweet caramel and toffee, chocolate, raisins and bananas, clove and vanilla, and a strong wheat bread flavor.  Alcohol is noticeable.  Tartness right before and into the finish.  Palate:  Medium bodied with a slightly creamy texture.  Medium carbonation.  Overall:  Tried this in a bottle last month and thought it was ok, but not great.  Had it on draft today, and man what a difference.  Flavors were great, aroma was terrific, nice creamy mouthfeel.  A totally different beer.

Bottle: Extremely lively when poured. I managed to pour half a litre of 100% head to begin with, so I had to wait for that to settle before continuing. Sweet banana-bubblegum aroma, but still kind of fresh. Head is - as you might have guessed: HUGE, creamy, long-lasting and off-white in colour. Colour is dark amber and hazy. Carbonation is lively, but even though it is a very good looking beer, Ill have to deduct one point because of big chunks of sediment from the bottle. Flavour is very fruity with some alcohol sweetness and lots of warmth. Mouth feel is filling, but not quite as full-bodied as one might suspect from an 8% beer, maybe because of the huge amounts of carbonation. Although this is a very good beer I am not quite as impressed as most others. Dont know if it is because the beer is too heavy for our present very hot summer weather, of maybe the big chunks of sediment put me off... Guess Ill have to try this one again in a couple of months.

Draft. Drawn fresh from the keg, this is an awe-inspiring beer bursting with unbelievable amounts of yeast, overripe banana and honey dew melon, and supported by a maddeningly addictive fullness not matched in any other dark weiss that I know of. Try this bottled, though, and you wonder what all the fuss is about -- personally, I havent touched a capped version of this for years. A real downside to this brew, however, is the whopping punch it delivers after a mere two tall glasses -- usually this undesirable quality is only found in beers of lesser quality.

This hefe-dopplebock pours cloudy raisin/mahogany, with a huge head and good retention.  The nose is of raisins, prunes, plums, dark fruit and spices.  It has sweetness indicative of dark fruits, figs, dates.  The light alcoholic finish and subtle carbonation lends to a zesty mouthfeel.  The light, latent heat in the esophagus is nice.  Good for an apertif or dessert brew!

What an aroma to kick this one off. Its its you hard with fruits,spices and an underlying alcohol. Appearance is just as nice. Pours a deep, deep red that is almost brown, but when the light hits it the orangy-red shows through. Great white head on it that really stuck around. Taste was really complete and had an amazing combination of citrus,cloves, and other spices. Has a sweetness to it that is quite pleasant. Finishes with a hit of bitterness that just seems to round it out perfectly.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2007 mmmm this smells wonderful. Reddish amber color.Very fruity, sweet, spicey smells. Tastes just like it smells. This is a VERY complex, sweet, alochol heavy brew. They should be proud of this one. Careful though, they go down deceptingly smooth for being 8%. A couple of these in one setting is all she wrote for me!

this is a great beer. when i first tried it i thought wow im going to check on ratebeer and if this didnt score well theres gotta be something wrong. Unsurprisingly the results speak for themselves. Has a big, long lasting head, flavour is great, carbonation great, aroma is like nothing else and has a nice lasting taste. i strongly recommened you try this beer, up there with some of the best ive tried

Bottled.  Pours a dark amber with a light tan head. The aroma is dominated by cloves, with a bit of citrus and toffee behind it. Creamy medium body and medium carbonation. The taste is sweet without being syrupy, again dominated by cloves, with some vanilla, bread and toffee leading to a spicy, very lightly bitter finish. The earlier comment of One for the holidays is pretty much spot on.

500ml Bottle: Its like Schneider has been reading my diary.  My first dark weiss I was already excited to try it, and not disappointed at all.  Pours a beautiful light leather brown with orange edging, and a hefty foam head that never quite left.  Pleasant aroma of bread, citrus, and pumpkin spices (ie. clove, cinnamon, licorice).  Absolutely amazing taste exactly as advertised.  Hits immediately with a citrus-heavy weiss punch that goes down smooth, trailing with the spices and a strong anise aftertaste.  Immediately afterwards you catch those bock tones and fades to a hoppish end.  Terrific all the way through, would have it again in a minute.

A malty, toasted, breadlike (yeasty) aroma, moderately doughy. The head on this one is a huge and frothy sight that reminded me of rising bread dough, could have just been the aroma influencing my senses. Smelled of a bit of raisin, vanilla, all-spice, a bit wine-like, with an ever so slightly alcohol odor. The froth had some serious hang time too. Off-white in color it complimented the clear, deep reddish orange color of the brew, which seemed kind of flat with a tiny hint of effervescense. The flavor was very spicy (Cinnamon & clove) which reminded me of Christmas time (that is Christmas night with a warming sensation radiating from the inside out as the brew travels from your tongue to your stomach. A pretty good beer overall but not good for me. One for the holidays.
slightly hazy dark brown with a large off white head.  Aroma is of banana, vanilla, caramel, and bread.  Taste is the same with some dark fruit showing through, spicy finish.

Bottled. Hazy reddish-brown color with impressive but vanishing head. Bready aroma with banana, smoke and berries. Bready, sweetish and warming flavor with notes of banana and dark fruits. The finish is silky, oily and warming. Great beer with deep flavors!

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2006 Huge, long-lasting bubbly head.  Dark brown/amber/reddish color.  Flavors were a complex blend of malt, caramel, a hint of raisin/fruit.  A great, great beer.  Extremely refreshing, easy to drink, not too heavy at all.

The Aventinus Dopplebock was a nice suprise. The pour was a very dark brown, with hues of red as well. The head was a quickly subsiding burst of bubbles the color of carmel. The aroma was very fruity and wine-like. The taste was very fruity, with a belgian quality to it. The finish was smooth and somewhat dry. A very nice brew."

Comes highly recommended so a lot to live up to.  Redish dark brown colour pours nicely out of the bottle, average size head, but long lasting.  Mild citrus hoppy aromas, with a touch of spice.  Slightly sweet taste, but not too much so.  Nice full body.

Muddy brown-red colour with great white head. Banana, fruitiness, some citrus and plums in the aroma. The taste is equally impressive, with the caramel taking over, lending a sweet edge to the taste. A lightly vinious touch enhances the fruity flavours in a long-lasting aftertaste.

big yellow-brownish head
nice hazy reddish dark-amber color
some smooth but too refreshing carbonation
smells yeasty,some banana, some clove ,some citrus,
tasts yeasty,banana and clove taste,something between pears and plums too, some citrus ,malty,some caramel,some alcoho, lperhaps i have too much fantasy,but i can even find,very hidden behind, something like black cherry

aftertaste yeasty, banana,clove,caramel,some warm alcohol
a very good, well balanced beer, alcohol is there but not in a harsh way¨
a good beer for nice evenings! i like it!

dark reddish brown pour with big head...sediment present...aroma is big in clove, banana, and caramel...flavor is quite strong and is comprised of sugary malts, spice, cinnamon, and has a big dopplebock backbone....nice palate, and a great beer

My first and problably last weizen bock. Too sweet for my likings. Lots of clove and banana. Just like a Hefe but with some caramel malts and a touch of roastiness. Too much sweetness in the finish too. A bit cloying and syrupy, but it got high points for aroma and appearance. Huge head and a nice purple brownish body.

I was expecting something a bit stronger, clovy aroma reminding me a lot of Franziskaner Dunkel. Fruity and malty. Sweet, fruity with a nice bitter finish on the tongue. Very nice, but didnt live up to the hype

Bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a ton (and I mean a ton) of carbonation.  I had to pour this into my dimpled mug in shifts.  The aroma has hints of fruit, with a really sweet tang.  The flavor is interesting.  Initially sweet with a nice bitter finish.  This beer kept improving the closer to room temperature it got to.  Nice yeast flavoring, and excellent choice of malts.  I was pleasantly surprised by this beer.
UPDATED: AUG 9, 2006 Rich juicy aroma with lots of fruit, apples, bananas, plums. very sweet. Mahagony color, Nice head. Unbelivable finish. Sweet malts. An excellent beer.

Pours murky brown with large head, which diminishes quickly without lacing. Sweet malty smell with some alcohol present, as well as fruit (banana/apple), certainly the cloves, and yeast. Flavor is what I would imagine a dunkelweizen/barleywine/dubbel concoction to taste like. Yeasty bread, sweet caramel, some banana, apparent alcohol, raisins. Perhaps my bottle is old, but Im not getting much bitterness in the finish, which makes it seem a little less balanced than it could be. Towards the end of the bottle, the carbonation drops considerably which seemed to highlight the sweetness and further imbalance the beer. I would probably choose this as a get-drunk-quickly beer, if I wanted to do so, because for 8%, it is very drinkable.
Dark, chocolaty taste.  Very scrumptious, but generally a little sweeter than I prefer my beer to be.  Extremely smooth with a great finish.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2007 Despite the 8%abv, there is absolutely no astrigency.  The flavors are of malt, caramel, banana, and slight coffee, chocolate and fruit.  This beer is so smooth and well balanced that you can easily drink a pint in a few large gulps.  However, the majesty of Aventinus is only appreciated by the winding journey through its complex flavors.  Im shocked and disturbed by the Danes who posted reveiws in the 2s - but mostly im sad for the land of Denmark that they alone are denied the supreme enjoyment of this highly and (I still believe) easily appreciable weizen bock.

Re-Rate: From 16.7 oz. bottle - More raisn flavor less caramel, and unfortunately some astringency.  A little whiskey on the nose.  Bottle Score - 4.0
bottle. dark golden color. meduim head. bannana-joe. same old same old. very alcohollic.
Bottle. Amber coloured with a small light head. Malty and slightæy roasted. Sweet with banana notes. Felles a bit artificial.
Magnificent beer, reminds me more of an abt/quadrupel than a weizen bock. Commercial description is very accurate. However (to the beers benefit), it finishes with various flavors and a strong punch.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2011 Nose was sweet, cloves and bananas; transparent highly carbonated brown body, with a thick beige head; flavor was spicy and sweet with cloves and finished with a tingle from the carbonation and a hoppy bite.

I know this is a highly respeted beer, but I was less then impressed, esp. considering how much it cost. The pour showed a nice dark brown-amber beer with a good head but after that the expierence was a little disappointing. It isnt a bad beer, but doesnt live up to the hype.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2007 Re-rate, March 07 on draft at Ludwigs: Fine stuff, no need to add more dribble to this text. Re-rate, Feb 07, non-vintaged bottle this time: Despite being an early review from me, my first one seems to do it justice. Slight alcohol detected this time through, probably because I bought the standard bottle unaged, but it was still wonderful, super delightful, very smooth, as good as a weizenbock can get. The rating is getting bumped a bit for its within style quality (a few more weizenbocks under my belt now). Having an Aventinus Weiznestarkbier glass made the crowned fluffy head and overall appearance all the better too. An excellent beer. Original rating follows with more descript comments.... Original rating: Bottle from 2001 batch. This one exceeded all expectations. Fantastic. Pour resulted in a brown-amber colored beer with a single finger of tan head on top. The head settled, but remained as a persistent (to the last sip) thin covering on top of the beer, that actually laced ok the whole drink. The aroma was sweet, clove-like, accompanied by bananas and a light roastedness. The flavor was based on a sweet weizen base with spices (cloves) and some roasted caramel type malts detected. Not as dry as many a dunkelweizen, and certainly richer and more complex, this one was very enjoyable. Dark fruits and chocolate hide beneath it all and come out more as it warms. Lots of stuff going on here, and the alcohol is super smooth. Ill have to try a recent bottling to see how this is unaged.

Pours a cloudy orangeish brown with a bigass light brown head.  Aroma is of yeast, bananas, cloves, raisins, caramel, and some wheat.  Taste is much of the same.  Tart up front, then some bitterness comes in, and then lots of cadied sugary sweetness on out.  Can definitely taste the alcohol.  Has characteristics of both bock and a weiss, though I think it leans more toward a weiss.  Very good.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Pours a cloudy brown color with a thick tan head.  Aroma is of dark fruits, lemon, wheat, caramel, and spices.  Flavor is the same, very well blended between the wheat flavor and the caramel and dark fruit flavor.  Very delicious brew, highley recommended.
Brownish purple in color. smooth sweet carmel taste. can also taste plums and other fruit. Great beer highly recommended.

Almost purple brown appearance with a thin head that holds but yields little lacing. Loads of carbonation bubbles continuously float up from the bottle of the glass.

Large wheat smell with some alcohol and chocolate malt.

Tastes are along the same lines being very sweet initially with some yeasty flavors initially and the alcohol flavor very strong in the finish.

This is a great beer that I cant get enough of. Delightful.

Huge, very dense & creamy brownish head over chestnut-amber beer, very hazy with yellowish highlights and an olive shine. Very typical Weizennose: fruity-estery with banana, cloves and expressly wheat; further candi-sugar like, caramelly, malt notes, but pretty clear. Sourish-sweetish main taste, coloured by very fruity esters (oranges and banana) and a spicey, peppery flavour that is also promoting a spritzy MF. Very clearly sourish wheat taste, but also lots of malts, sweet & caramelly. All sounding very stereotypical for a Weizen, but indeed, this is very lively, characterful and very balanced. Spritzy MF, with a lot of body behind it, wheat slickness in a very pronounced way, alcoholwarming. Another Schneider classic. Strange tat the leading brewery produces also top quality. Something InBev, A-B or SABMiller can only dream of.

Tried this side by side with Aventinus Vintage 2001 and enjoyed them both very much.  Its very easy to see and taste the differences between the two.  This was spritzier and lighter than the vintage.  Very nice and the glass is awesome.  It lets everyone in the restaurant know you mean business.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2006 Bottle, 500ml. This is heaven. Pours with a very clean head. The colour, mahogany and ever so vibrating will eventually get you. The aroma is full of toffee. This feels like oil with bubbles. It is so complex its hard to understand it. One of the few beers to smoke with a good Cuban. The aftertaste is mature and contains both black chocolate and smoke. The flavour doesnt get full points because it could be stronger. And more. In the glass.
Bottle. Medium head with short duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma is dominated by spices. Taste is sweet and spicy. Greal good weizen bock.

Bottled. Murky, dark amber-brown with a small, frothy, light-brown, mostly diminishing head. The aroma is moderately malty with sweet notes of toasted grain; hoppy with light notes of herb and lemon; lightly yeasty with a light note of cobweb; moderate notes of banana, clove and wood. The flavor was moderately sweet, lightly acidic and lightly bitter with an average-to-long finish with a lightly sweet, lightly acidic. The body was medium, the texture was velvety and the carbonation was lively.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2006 (Bottle BB 24/04/07; ABV 8.2%) Yeasty, fruity (banana/strawberry) and slightly alcohol aroma. Orange brown colour, muddy (small sedimentation) and white, average size, slightly lasting head with a hint of lacing. Banana/strawberry, yeasty, spicy flavour. Medium to full-bodied, lively carbonated and slightly alcohol (warming) palate. Excellent, tasty, Weizen Bock! 22/09/07 (original rating was 8/4/8/4/15)

2001 bottle.  Highly carbonated (due to age?), poured with a HUGE, white head to compliment a deep red body.  Initially smells of grapes/raisins and wheat.  The taste follows up the smell - very fruity with low alcohol presence.  Letting the beer set for about 10 minutes brings a balance of sugary/sweet flavor and bitterness to the finish.

My first review, so take with a grain of salt. This is just what my young palate was able to pick up.

Poured a dark ruby color with a beautiful off-white inch thick head.

Nose was slightly chocolate, fruity banana-like esthers. 

I drank some without the yeast, and some with:
w/out: crisp carbonation up front leading to pleasant sweetness in the middle with tons of flavor and complexity I cannot even begin to describe (maybe one day). I did pick up on the spicy clove finish that the bottle describes, and finally an alcoholic warming of the tongue.
with: raisney fruitiness giving way to yeasty flavor. Flavors similar to w/out but even more complex and pleasing.

The mouthfeel was creamy and smooth--about what I expected. 

I drank this slightly hungry just to make sure I could get it all down, but I ended up still getting quite full from this beer. Im sure experience BAs could handle it with no problem, but I got quite full and surely felt that 8.2%. Its very deceptive. Make sure you take you time with this one. I imagine this would go well with grilled pork chops.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2006 It was very pleasing  to finally find a beer worth writing about here in Regensburg, Germany. Most of the poor lewdies in this town think highly of their beer, which is on the whole mediocre in quality (it should be noted that the nationalist spin is that Regensburgs Bier ist par excellence).The most sad arrangement is that they have no imports--Belgium is right next door, but the local beer owners and high-minded locals have never heard of Trappist ale (schade!). I was feeling downright sorry for the locals, especially given the strong, nationalistic propaganda about how good their beer is; after tasting the Aventinus, though, I cheered up a bit. Now  I know they arent missing out entirely (one good beer is better than none, and in this case, ignorance is far from bliss). This offering has a spicy, melon-laced aroma with solid, effervescent, well-rounded flavor--its sweet, but not cloyingly so, and the malts are balanced out. If you make a trip through Regensburg, ignore most everything and head for the Aventinus.

On tap at Wine Exchange of Sonoma. This dark brown ale poured with a massive tan head and a sweet caramel aroma.  The flavor is amazingly intense for a wheat beer, and the hops and malt are quite well balanced.  A very nice brew.

Bottle I picked up at zenos.
Pours a generous head!
Aroma is sweet, pleasant aroma.
Dark amber/brownish color with decent head.
Flavor is jam packed. Very nice mixture of malts and hops. Good amount of yeast.
A Really Great Weizen-Bock. One I will drink again.
Cheers!
nice red hue and has a nice sweet spice aroma.  found it to be a little bitter for my liking, but otherwise very good bock style beer.

500mL bottle: Pours a huge slightly tan head, big bubbles, quickly diminshing, good lacing.  Brown/reddish in color, small carbonation bubbles.  Strong aroma of dark fruit, plum, some malts, lots of different aromas.  Light fruit taste, perfume, smooth aftertaste, slight alcohol.  Reminds me a lot of a abt quad.  Tasty, but alcoholy.

Pours a hazy, very dark chocolate brown with dark copper tinge; has an off-white, very fizzy head that surprising lasts extremely long.  Nose is very clovey, as expected, with smaller hints of banana and plum.  The taste is nearly delectable with the clove flavor still being upfront with chocolate, caramel, plum, banana, and citrus flavor backing the sweetnees.  Only a touch of acidity and mild hop bitternes meet the tongue.  Palate is lively with carbonation, yet still remains somewhat creamy with a medium-full body.  Finally finishes with a sweet caramel flavor along with a slight acidity that actully is mildly refreshing(as with normal hefes).  This one runs a fine line between, drinkable, complex, and refreshing.  A beer that I would love to drink a few during the late spring months.  A must try for bock drinkers and hefeweizendrinkers alike.

Excellent beer. I was pleasantly surprised. First by the beautiful amber/brown colour, than by the generous creamy head that lasted right until the end. Superb aroma and nice taste of fruits (maybe a hint of rasberry?) and wheat. Enjoy!

Pours dark copper with an ooff-white head that goes away fairly quickly.  Aromas is very rich and sweet with some creaminess - fruit is detected as well.  The aroma is very big. Mouthfeel is medium / full and very creamy carbonation.  Taste is creamy roasted malt with butterscotch and toffee.  Very rich and dessert-like.  Finish has lots of toffee and a bit of sourness.  An amazing beer.

Bottle, at Arne  & Inge.
Redbrown with a large light brown head. Aroma heavy malty (caramel, fruit). Flavor heavy sweet, powerful. Full body, syrupy, soft carbonated. Heavy in alcohol.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2007 A German Dopplebock that drinks like a yeasty Belgian. Is there a better beer? No adjectives, just know if you like either style, this beer is near-perfect. Well, only thing wrong may be a slightly off color. OK, Im reaching. The perfect beer.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours a brown color with a with a  off-white head. Aroma of wheat, bananas, and spices. Flavor is smooth, carbonated, bananas, spices, wheat, sweet, and  smooth.

Bottle. Pours murky brown with nice white head. Nice aroma of fruity esters and carmelized sugar. Flavor of sweet dark wheat malt, along with banana, purple grapes, and tropical fruit. Smooth mouthfeel, easy to drink, and no detection of alcohol. Simply a great beer.

Brown bottle, 500 ml, 8,0 %; eye: opaque brown with burgundy and orangey reflections, nice white head, a bit of effervescence, suprsingly no lacing; nose: caramelized malt, spices, citrusy, yeast; mouth: you can hear it "pop and crackle" like Rice Crispies, full body, caramel, bitterness, dark chocolate, average bitterness, a hint of acidity and sourness, creamy texture, nice carbonation, long finale where the peppery side of the alcohol expresses itself, lightly sweet

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 500 ml; oeil : brune opaque avec des reflets bourgogne et orangé, belle mousse beige, un peu deffervescence; nez : malt caramélisé, épices, citrique, levure; bouche : tu peux l« entendre » comme des Rice Crispies, ronde en bouche, caramel, amertume, dark chocolate, moyennement amère, pointe sûrette et acidique, texture crémeuse, très bonne carbonatation, finale où le côté poivré de lalcool prend le dessus, légèrement sucrée
Dark, cararmelly brown color.  A decent amount of head.  Good body. Some yeastiness.  Very nice mouthfeel.  Very drinkable.  Surprised by the 8% abv.

Brown color. Huge ever-growing sustaining head and intense carbonation. Aroma of banana and cloves. Flavor evolves mainly around banana and cloves with some caramel and perhaps milk-chocolate. Quite sweet with a sour finish. Very round, luxurious mouthfeel. Despite being quite sweet and nevertheless its strong alcohol content, VERY drinkable, dangerous actually. My only complaint is it felt a little dull in the end since the carbonation was down. Yet, one of my all-time favorites.

Bottle.  Pours a somewhat murky dark brown with a nice, lasting beige head.  Aroma is complex... when first opened and poured cold, it was mainly fruity/banana with some clove, but as it warmed it took on more of a chocolate/plum character.  Nice creamy and carbonated mouthfeel.  Initially very malty, but fades into a dried fruit, cherry/date, yeasty middle finally finishing with a bit of alcohol and stickyness.   Yummy.

Brewery aged 2001 bottle.  Birch beer in color with tan head that dissipates completely.  Aroma is of stewed fruit, apricot, and dark malt.  Fairly soft and round on the palate with enough carbonation to make it crisp.  Taste is of dark malt, slightly fruity, traces of coffee and clove.  Five years has mellowed this usually very potent beer.  I prefer a fresh Aventinus, but this is a nice change.

2001.  fruity aroma of grape juice, alcohol, caramel malts and a hint of spices.  brown ruby color.  loud, lively, large, off white head.  a fruity beer with dark spicey malts.  tastes similar to a dubbel.  med- light bodied.  the wheat adds a lightly sour finish.

Bottle 14-04-06 purchased from Sainsburys, Kidlington, they are selling this at 96p a bottle in my local Sainsburys instead of £1.91. Dark Ruby colour, sweet wheaty taste with some hops, spicy aroma, very good beer, suprised that it is 8% as it does not taste this strong. Might go and stock up on some more!

14 Mar 2006 - Nice sweet malt, spicy hopped aroma.  Cloudy dark brown-red colour, good head and suds lacing.  Sweet light wheat fruit and spicy hop flavour.  Thickish mouthfeel with a malty tangy hopped aftertaste.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2007 Phenomenal beer.  Pours clear mahogany with a small head.  Aroma of spices and cloves with some banana.  Taste of malts with spice and some darker fruits a little of the hefe banana.  Smooth mouthfeel with a sweet finish.  The alcohol is totally masked.  Will definitely get this one again.
Draught at Glöckl Bräu, Graz, Austria. -dark ruby coloured, medium brown head, nice fresh fruity aroma with clove notes and spicy hints, bitter and slight acidic finish

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2006 A delicious and wondefully dark and complex beer. While darkish in color the body remains light but with certain depth that requires slow sipping. A wonderful taste and feel in the mouth, with a suprising alchol content.  Very nice and delicious. It can be found at Electro Lounge in  OKC

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2013 First ratingBottle from Swedish "Systembolaget" on November 30, 2005.Beautiful dark color with a huge head. Not the typical wheat scents or flavors, but a rich balanced flavor that I can have more of.8/5/8/4/17=4.2RerateDraught at Charlies, Copenhagen, on July 10, 2009Cloudy brown color, tan head. Estery banana scent. Banana, spicy taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness.8/4/8/3/16=3.9RerateAs "Tap 6"50 cl bottle thanks to ekstedt! Sampled on March 24, 2012BB 2012.09.07Murky brown color, smalish brown head. Banana, acidic, spicy scent. Moussy mouthfeel, low bitterness. Spicy, clove, dry taste.7/3/7/3/13=3.3RerateAs "Schneider Weisse Tap 6 Unser Aventinus", 50 cl bottle from my fridge, I purchased it at Systembolaget a while back.BB 2011.08.18, hmm guess it was more than "a while back" I got this...Sampled on December 31, 2013.Clear brown color, fizzy tan head. Alcohol, ripe banana, solvents scent. Full, rich, sweet, toffee taste. Warming alcohol. Fizzy mouthfeel, low bitterness.Aroma has lost some, taste has gained some. Still holds up, good beer!6/3/8/3/15=3.5
Purchased at Greenshields, Cary NC.  Really citrusy aroma, but the peluliar thing was how the bubbles were perfeclty round.  The head diminished fro outside in.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2006 A beer with a mouthfeel so substantial that it feels like food in your mouth, almost like drinking buttermilk.  the aroma was light, yet pleasingly fruity and yeasty.  Taste was of sweet cherries and a heavily malted character.  I drank two pints of this with a delicious sausage platter and it played superbly with the saltiness of the mustards and kraut.  Very nice.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2010 16.9 oz bottle.  Cloudy orange-brown with a chunky off-white head that lasts.  Malty, wheaty with nutmeg and cardamon.  Bubbly but with body.  Flavor like nose but also get Circus Peanuts and limey end.  Very solid.  2/27/10 - 2004 Vintage bottle.  Quickly fading head with lots of chunks and bits.  Nose a bit more subdued than fresh with a spoiled fruit tang.  Taste has really faded with some raisin, sour port and a dry woody finish.  I would have given this a 3.5.

WOW... This beer is fun to drink! Fruity and carmel taste. Nice off-white head that stays well. Leaves a nice bite on your tongue and a slight bitter lingering taste on the palate. Eat something before you drink this 1! haha The streets of Munich were tilting after a few of these guys! I loved this beer.

Pours a darkish brown with giant head.  Cloves prominent.  Bananas and some citrusy flavors also evident.  Somewhat sweet and malty.  Finish is bitter and dry.  Not my favorite style, but a solid beer.

This pours a mixture of dark brown and amber, with a tan foamy head. Glass gives off a gentle, furity aroma. I enjoyed the spicy taste throughout the glass, and it left a long, good finish. Will definitely be drinking this again.

500 ml bottle. Two years past its best before end date. Coarse thin off-white head. Heavily carbonated. Clear brownish and ruby-red in color. Sweet malty and appley aromas. Notes of caramel and dark bread can also be detected. Slightly oxidized. Full-bodied. Not really particularly sweet for the style. Quite possible that some of the remaining sugars have been eaten by yeast to produce the high carbonation level. Wonderful texture; soft and slightly buttery, but also crisp from the carbonation touching the tongue. Caramel and apple flavours. Aftertaste is lightly bitter. Leaves a viscous feeling on the tongue.
Pours a ruddy red/brown with a ample sized head.  Tastes of hoppiness, caramels, yeast, and fruity.  A solid beer throughout, finished strong with a nice bitterness.

Yikes...this one is a much bigger boy than I expected.  Pours a perfect brown amber with an intensely dense and foamy head.  Aroma is spicey and plumy...of course some wheat and alcohol as well.  Flavor is great and unique.  Wheat, alcohol, pepper, anise, plums,yeast, and raisins.  Mouthfeel was very smooth and a bit heavy.  This shit was great.

Aroma was fruity and carmelly if that is possible. This beer tasted alot like it smelled. It was really smooth without the strong alcohol that I expected. The first half of the bottled poured and drank and looked like brandy. The second half looked like a cloudy homebrew and had an increased slight yeasty flavor. Overall this was a good beer but for the money there are a number of beers I would choose over it, but it has a novel wineish palate wash to it.

Dark brown body with an initially big, fizzy, off-white head. The aroma is banana, wheat and cloves. The flavor is wheat, caramel, toffee, cinnamon and apples. The finish is long, slightly bitter and a bit tart as well. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy with lively carbonation that bites the tongue. Impressive.

Pours a brown color with a with a large billowing off-white head. Aroma of wheat, bananas, and spices. Flavor is smooth, carbonated, bananas, spices, wheat, sweet, and very smooth. Good body, Great brew.

Dark brown and thick with clouds, with a an ample dense cream coloured head (they dont get much better looking than this).  A lot of cloves/banana typical aromas from a weizen, but theres a good deal of complexity-- cinnamon, molasses, caramel.  The palate is completely creamy, frothing up as soon as it hits my tongue.  When it dwindles down, theres still some considerable thick/sudsy/chewy/slippery texture to go along with the alcohol warming.  The flavor surpasses the aromas complexity.  Banana and cloves are immediate, apples, cinamon, honey, cream, caramel, grainy wheaty malt, and, of course, alcohol.  Theres a sour apple finish with lingering hops (the only place in this beer I really tasted them).  I really dont like wiezens, and yet I really thoroughly enjoy this beer! (and am not just appreciating it for what it is)

Big lasting white head.  Brown cloudy beer.   Aroma is bananas/pears/cloves, soy sauce.  Smells is very fruity whereas the flavour is a bit more complex.  Tastes like raisins, sweet, and malty.  Flavorful finish lingering fruity bitterness.

Deep amber under a big effervescing off white head. Banana, sour yeast, and raisins in a huge inviting aroma. Thick mouthfeel and a lively carbonation. Clove, banana, dark fruits, and brown sugar all contribute to a complex flavor. A little sour in the finish, but there is enough bitterness to leave the finish clean. This is a wonderful beer.

A tough poor, poured it carefully into a big mug, only to be rewarded with a 4 inch head that filled up the rest.  The aroma was nice and full, ranging from banana to more grainy smell.  Flavor has nice maltiness, nice weight with very well placed sour hint to it.  A fair number of seemingly disparate elements that combine to make a quality beer. A definite recommendation.

An ugly duckling for sure, pours the color of pureed raisins with a thick tannish head.  Huge aroma of artificial bannana and clove and ginger and darker fruits.  Some unsweetened chocolate along with more clove, artificial bannana and yeast in the mouth.  Huge malts presence of course.  Slightly cloying.  Huge beer.  this would be outstanding with kraut and brats.
It was a nice change but not one Id drink on a regular basis. A little too fruity and spicey for my tast. Reminded me of spiced cider.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2006 Bottle.  Poured a hazy amber with a thick light-tan, almost white, head.  The aroma was faintly sour, but then sweet and richly floral.  That carries in to the flavor which is at first sweetly floral maturing into a rich maltiness with hints of dried fruit and aromatic herbs.  The finish is a just barely bitter rounding out a very rich beer.  Smooth and balanced in the mouth it drinks nicely.
Draught. Brownish colour. Powerful spice aroma and taste. Nice palate. Alcoholic aftertaste.
Draught. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Brown colour. Powerfull aroma with hints of cinnamon. Very good flavor aswell. Creamy palate. A very good beer.

Bottle  Pours a murky brown with a huge creamy white light brown head, which is mostly lasting with good lacing.  Has a complex aroma.  At first I get sweet perfume,  then you get chocolate malts with plenty of good spices and some bubble gum.  Has a smooth palate with easy drinking flavor.  Light on carbination and lacks some finish but has a nice duration.  Has a medium body.  The alcohol is very well hidden.  The flavors really come out, even taste some cherry.  Very easy drinking, sips extremely well.
Malt spiritus fruit hop aroma. Murky brown colour with excellent head and lacing. Smooth malt fruit flavour that lingers. Smooth palate.

Beer pours a very dark tea color with a large soapy head.  That foam lasts and leaves a significant lacing.  Very appealing in appearance.  First taste is of malty caramel but the caramel faded.  In its place was a strong banana and clove combination that was delicious.  The malt flavor remained but fell to the back.  This is a wonderfully crafted beer and is a great style.  This one was stumbled upon and what a great find it was!

UPDATED: APR 13, 2006 Review No. 200.  Bottled.  Muddy, murky pour.  Quite a yeasty appearance, in fact.  Head laces well, white-to-eggshell in color, and is probably the noisiest head Ive heard (despite no visible carbonation.  Light, sweetish nose, lightly spiced with caramel.  Typical Hefe flavors are subdued.  Very thick caramel taste to start, alcoholic but not offensively so.  Strong.  Dark sweet malt of a well-made bock without the stickiness, though not cloying.  Add to that the wheat of a Hefe.  Light and fruity notes in the background.  Medium body.  Fantastic Weizenbock.  My friend finds that the sweetness detracts from the complexity.  Im inclined to agree. [3.8]
Re-rate: Second bottle much the same as the first.  The noisy head really is something, isnt it?.  Conditions were slightly better this time, though the comments of the first rating hold.  Spice is coming through more earnestly this time, though, adds a disproportionally high amount of complexity to the final product.  Cheers to this major-league brew!

From the bottle
Pours a deep reddish brown with a big foamy head. 
The aroma is strongly clove-and-flambe bananas, with a hint of booze and a hint of agar. The flavor follows suit, curiously spicy, with a bitter flourish on the roof of the mouth --- yet gentle on the tongue like warm herbal tea. 
This is clearly an outstanding beer, and yet Im not completely clicking with it. I think the fault likes in my palate and not in the craftsmanship with which this one has been produced. Itll be good to revisit under different circumstances.

16 oz bottle at Federal in Durham, NC. Bottle conditioned. Served in a tall 0.5 L Aventinus glass. Hazy garnet-brown color with foamy tan head. Smells of bananas, cloves, and alcohol. Citrusy flavor, slightly sweet with a touch of caramel, cloves, and a splash of alcohol at then end.

pours murky brown with huge head, visible carbonation, and minimal lacing.  aroma of fruit, banana, and spice, taste of cherry, citrus, and wheat with a very distinct glove finish.  decent but not really my thing.

Super huge bubbly head.  Drown pour.  Definate hops scent with some caramel and bitter fruit, maybe some sour pear.  Mixed taste, a lot of berry and bitter malts.  Lingering aftertaste.  Pretty pleasant.

WOW.  Smells like a hefeweizen, bananas, cloves with slight hints of malt.  Tastes amazingly refreshing for a beer so dark and high in ABV.  Alcohol is nonexistent in taste.  Has a crisp finish.  Im impressed.

500 mL bottle.  Rich, smooth mouthfeel.  Soothes the throat like honey.  Also has some honey in the flavor, which plays with the alcohol nicely.  Nutty maltiness throughout.  Surprisingly, some tart sourness in the back, evoking cherries, grapes and cranberries.  Clove is certainly in there as well.  This is a good beer out of the bottle, but it really explodes on tap.  Unfortunately, this review is just of the bottle.

Bottle brewed in 2001. Pours a hazy orange rust color with a super fizzy head. A very fruity aroma, cherry and cloves are coming to mind as well as a little alcohol. The taste is sweet and fruity as well...getting the same cherry/clove comination as well as some mild alcohol flavor. This is a very carbonated beer with, again, a mild alocohol burn in a couple spots with a very dry finnish. Its pretty light all the way across the tounge and comes out pretty refreshing if a bit too carbonated.
tis mighty the f tasty. and having of alcohol I love it like I love mike Cocle

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2006 Draught (7-4-7-3-15=3.6)  Fresh fruity nose with lots of Banana in it, later it reveals deeper spicy malt notes (not really any bock character in the nose); It has a super fresh body with some fill to it and an incredible sparkle (champagne-like); The bock character appears in a very long finish together with the classic acidity of the weizen beer. Somehow a strange beer, not typically bock neither a typically weizen.

Bottle  Brown unclear with huge white head that falls fast; Clove, banana, raisins, bock character in a quite big nose; Very well balanced body with some acidity and a huge carbonation; Exploding finish, huge, chewy because of complexity, not because it is super thick, is it long too. Great beer with lots of character, better then the draught version.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2013 Deep brown-red colour with a thick white head. The aroma is really complex, there is spices, clove, apple, banana, alcohol... It is full bodied,  taste is very complex too, with spices, clove, banana and caramel, really malty. Excellent beer overall. The 8% of alcohol is well hidden.
Bottle. Had a little bit from my friends.  Quite good actually.  Slightly fruity flavor, with roasted malt on top.

Sampled from bottle provided by dickinsonbeer. Poured a deeper reddish/brown color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas and tastes of bananas, cloves, wheat and some citrus. Newer bottle tried next to a 99 vintage. The 99 was oxidized and quite boring while the newer one rocked.
Thanks to dickinsonbeer.  Pours a red/brown amber with an average off white head.  Aroma of banana, wheat, light citrus and some roasted malts.  Flavors of the same, nice and smooth.

Bottle and on-tap.  It was a rich redish brown color.  It had a huge creamy white head somewhere between 2-3 inches tall and it did not go away fast.  When I had Aventinus on-tap at the Brick Store Pub in Decatur it had a very pronounced taste of clove and was very complex with hints of fruits and a slight banana flovor. It was listed as 9.4% ABV, but youd never know it.  I couldnt wait to get a bottle from Greens and try it again.  I did. One word, BANANA!  Thats it nothing else came through. I found Aventinus again at another place and got another bottle.  It was almost like what I had on-tap.  I think it has to do with the age of the beer.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2007 Pours a tawny amber color w/ a full, semi creamy froth. Superb hangtime receding to a full ring and canopy lace. Aromas of malted bananas and mildly medicinal. Medium nectar w/ ample residual effers. The texture expands to pillowy soft and chewy effers. Mildly sweet w/ a predominance of malt character. Flavors of spicey banana bubble gum, slight medicine, angotura bitters, rootbeer, and a touch of sour dark fruit that persits from start to finish. The finsh is long w/ a mild sweetness and a tart bittering component.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2008 Bottle. Tasted again, more than 18 months since the last time. I just thought that I should add that my first thought when smelling it this time, was a fine Belgian triple. Theres some of that thoughts when I taste it as well, and it leaves me warm inside, and very content. A really lovely weizenbock. By the way, I think I remember the Weizen Bock from Haandbryggeriet (N) to be a bit fizzy, but Im not sure anymore, as Aventinus has a quite heavy carbonation as well. Anyhow, Im really fond of Aventinus, and my rating stands unaltered. (070912)Bottled. Slightly hazy, amber beer with a thick, beige head. Heavy aroma with sweetness, toffee, cloves, dried fruits, a little banana and a hint of alcohol. It is quite fizzy in the mouth, but not as sticky as expected, and flavors of caramell, cloves, hops, alcohol, banana and dried fruits swirls around your mouth along with some yeasty notes, finishing off in a sweet, yet bitter, warming aftertaste that leaves you very satisfied. Full-bodied classic beer, and it was a good choice for this cold, snowy evening. It left me very pleased. (060216)
Bottle: Rich, deep dark brown coffee color, thick foamy yellow head. Spicy wintery aroma complements the initial sweet fruit tastes. Finishes in spice with clove notes. Very nice.

Clear amber pour with lots of bubbles.  Spicy aroma, reminds me of alcohol.  Smooth easy drink.  Full bodied, with hints of apple and caramel.  Finishes a bit bitter and sour.  Well balanced beer.  Great beer for the winter season.

Beer #100!!! Here we go!
Bottle. Pours a beautiful hazy red, with a generous bubbly off-white head.
Aroma is sweet malty caramel. Spicy. Hint of yeast. Very promising...
Alcoholic sweet flavor. Malt, caramel. Fruity and yeasty. Slightly bitter, alcoholic aftertaste.
Medium-to-full body. Rather heavyish carbonation. Gassy.
A wonderfully warming beer for cold winter evenings.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2006 Very Intriguing brew. Aroma full of fruit yet subtly wheat. To much carbonation.Sweet malty flavor makes it easy on the taste buds. Good overall character. I personally like the clove finish.

Bottle: Dark cloudy ruby colour with a heavy white head. Aroma of ripe red fruits, strong wheat presence. Taste is complex, a mixture between a great wheat beer and a doppelbock without losing one or the other, alcohol is nicely hidden.
Is a bit fruity, with a slightly nutty taste.  Highly carbonated.  Very good complement to a meal, but not interesting enough on its own

Bottle.  Pours a clear brown with red tints, has a small white head.  Aroma is strong of yeast, some fruit notes and wheat.  flaor is of a wheaty belnd with dried nuts and fruit.  There is a slight peppery flavor to it.  Medium carbonated mouthfeel.  Pretty good.
[bottle] Murky brown color. Smells like strong yeast and fruits. Taste is excellent. Dried fruits, plum, nutty malts. Good wheat background. Very nice.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2006 Pours deep amber into an english pint with a massive head -- which constantly recedes.  Raisins, pepper and soy aromas.  Full-bodied and creamy.  Upfront caramel malts and clove -- slightly sweet.  Lasting roasted honey finish.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2007 My biggest complaint about this beer is that it (the bottle)  looks cheap and like every other poorly rated european beer.  That aside its a pretty good beer.  Has a sweet malty character and a little bit of that bubblegum flavor.  Due to lack of clean glassware I drank it from the bottle but it looks great in that picture.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Cheap, too.  <$3 for 500ml

rerate.  I was too imature when i first drank this to really appreciate it.  Lately Ive been on a dunkleweizen and weizen bock kick.  I decided to revisit this.  This is awesome.  Lots of esters with a silky texture and some sweet kind of chocolately notes.  not as good as ramstein winter wheat but close.  further rerate.  i had this on tap a month or so ago, and Im drinking a bottle now.  it was phenomenal, very lush, from the bottle is totally delicious too.  when you factor everything, price, flavor, alcohol content, availability, this might be the best beer ever.

Bottle.  For some reason, I always tend to overlook German beers.  It probably has something to do with the large glare coming from the Belgian section right next to the Germans.  Whatever.  This is one damn fine beer.  Overactive head, but it was fluffy and dissipated rather quickly.  Great aroma.  Banana, bubblegum, clove and chocolate all in the nose.  One of the better aromas out there.  Its a little light, and thats the only thing keeping it from a 10.  Spicy and sweet mouthfeel.  Very active carbonation in the mouth as well.  Great flavor to match the nose.  Somewhat vinous, but not too much.  Also the aforementioned chocolate, banana, bubblegum and cloves.  Very good beer.  This ones for Dortmunder.

Aventinus is a dunkle weizen bockbier or "dark wheat bock beer" by style. It is one of the most complex and amazing beers that you will ever taste, and beer geeks world wide sing its praises. I have enjoyed this beer countless times here in the US, but to experience this one fresh vom fass at Weisses in Munich, was an almost spiritual experience. This beer is brewed with up to 60% dark wheat malt, along with a very distinctive ale yeast strain that produces estery aromas and flavors of clove, banana, and apple. Being a bockbier, this beer has strong aromas and flavors of alcohol, and packs quite a punch at over 8% abv. It was a phenomenal beer to match with my breakfast of sausages and pretzels, and one of the most amazing beers to ever pass my lips. 

Aventinus pours to a beautiful, murky and opaque, deep caramel color, with a big, tall, rocky white head, and a vibrant carbonation. . The nose on this beer is very complex, and packed with character. Aromas of sweet malt, nutty malty, clove, and aromas of ripe banana flood the nose. This is paired with peppery hints of alcohol. The palate is smooth and round on the tongue, with big sweet and caramel malt flavors, some tart wheat malt flavor, and an underpinning of estery fruit. Aventinus finishes with more complex and delicious, malt and fruit flavors, then ends with a slightly warming, malty and clove spicy finish that lingers. 

A true master piece of the brewers art, this beer fresh vom fass was a truly special beer. If that were not enough, around 10am, a lederhosen clad Ompah band walks in, sets up at a table directly behind where I was seated, and strikes up the music. The combination of the atmosphere, food, music, happy people, and of course beer, was without question one of the most, or perhaps even, the most amazing beer drinking experiences of my life. My friend, a veteran of Munich beer halls, commented to me, "This is not done for tourists you know. Look around you. There are no tourists in here. This is what Bavarians do.". If you ever decided to venture to Germany, a trip to Weisses Brauhaus is a must, and Aventinus is a must try. I enjoyed a few liters of this beer, as well as Schneider Weisse. We had such a great time, we didnt get out of there until about Noon, and to say I left blissful, is an under statment of a life time.

Bottle: Dark amber, small but stable off-white head; vinous nose (Port), aromas of dried fruit (raisins) and bananas; slightly sweetish and moderate fruity flavour, medium to full bodied; sweet malty, distinctive fruity and a bit yeasty finish, some faint illusions of cloves. Yeah, a devilishly deceptive and moreish Weizen Bock !
I cant believe I have not rated this yet. Nose ansd taste are both laden with something I might expext from a Westy 8. Loads of dark fruit and exotic spices.There is an undertone of terra firma.

Bottle. This came highly recommended from a waitress who as well is a beer hound. This is her fave, and I must say, it is one of my new favourites as well now! Very nice dark brown pour (from the bottle), good head. Very, very satisfying, filling flavour.

"MMMMMMMMM poured a dark red/brown color with a nice tan head which left some lacing. Aroma was good cloves and dark fruits. Flavor was good real good, yeasty sweet some banana? A complex beer which was great. "
My new favorite.  IMO tastes best if it warms up a little.  Strong initial taste(high alcohol content?), but really good.  If you are in the DFW area, $3.39 at World Market!
Alight cloudy brown pour with a large off-white head. Has aroma of banana and nuts.  flavor was malty but very pleasing. A great choice for any occasion.

On Tap at  Flying Pie on Fairview:  This wonderfully expensive ($5 for 12 oz) and tasty beer is cloudy brown as seen in the picture.  It has rich aromas of dates, figs and olives.  It has other complexities in the tastes such as a small dose of saddle soap and grass clipping.  It has a sweet finish and hides the 8% alcohol well.  It has a slight silage aftertaste that flirts with a hefeweizen.  Pretty good.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2006 This beer is very similar to and is as complex tasting as some of the best Belgian Strong Dark Ales that Ive had.  It has a little more Caramel malt flavors tho and a stronger banana /yeasty ester flavor base.  A damn Good brew no doubt.  A little on the sweet side, but in this beer that isnt a bad thing at all, in fact it defines the brew.

Bottle-Yum, drank it before I ever looked up the ratings, so I was happily surprised.  The aroma was mostly fruity bananas with a touch of clove. The plate was perfect leaving behind a touch of sour on the back of the tongue and the roof of the mouth.  Great stuff.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2006 Really good beer.  Aroma was sweet fruity even, chocolate.  Appearance was very impressive.  Extremely dark with nice thick head.  Palate was smooth and full bodied.  Flavor was a rich sweetness of fruit and chocolate.  Very well balanced. Excellent!

Bursting with aroma of figs, walnut and maple, lightly coated with melon overtones.  Burnt copper color, with light bubbly quickly dissipating head.  Clear.  Solid flavor, fruity without really tasting like fruit.  Banana, and some fig provides a taste of sweetness coupled nicely with clove.  Amazingly good balance, with the flavor and carbonation as well.  little bubbles floating up like champaigne throughout the drink.  A great beer!

This is a really interesting style of beer.  I just kind of stumbled on it while considering my next batch of home brew.  I found a clone recipe and was lucky enough to find a commercial version to try.  The head does not linger or is it long lasting as described...for this one the carbonation is locked in. Theres some fruitiness in the aroma that is beating around the bush.  You dont get a good sense for it until you take a sip.  The effervescent bubbles finally show up and the aroma comes to life.  This one is fruity and slightly tart on the tongue. I can taste cherries and other spices.  The malt flavors come through but is nicely balanced by the adjuncts.  The alcohol plays a bigger role that it should in the taste but overall this is a really good beer.
sweet herby aroma with hints of clove and vanilla, cloudy brown color with a thick, creamy head.  complex flavor, a bit sweet, hints of clove, banana, spices

Pours with a humongous off-white head on a slightly cloudy golden-brown body. Strong malty aroma with lots of banana, nuts and spices. Very yeasty. Strong malty-banana taste on a spicy, thick body that coats the inside of the mouth.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2011 Bottle on 04/03/2011 from Once Upon a Vine - South.  Murky dark brown body with a medium creamy off-white head with lacing clinging to the glass. Rich spice, caramel, bananas and fruit aroma. Sweet spice flavor, some caramel, bready and toasty malt with light banana. Medium body with moderate carbonation. 8/3/8/3/16 - 3.8

01/07/2006 - Cloudy brown color with a thick creamy light brown head. Aroma of spice and bananas. Malty flavor with hints of caramel and bananas.  9/4/8/3/16 - 4.0

Pours a dark murky brown color with an extremely thickish white head.  Aroma is full of fresh yeast and sweet spices, primarily nutmeg,wheat,cloves and bananas.  Taste is a carbonated mix of slightly sweet spices, including nutmeg with hints of cloves,wheat, banana and bread dough.  Excellent !!

Pours cloudy brown with medium white head.  Nose is wheat, yeast, slightly off banana, clove.  The flavor begins with musty wheat, segues to banana, finishes with clove.  Nice full mouthfeel.  There are barest hints of plum and olive as well.   Nice peppery finish.  Sticks to the tongue, and very heavy body.  Leaves the peppery taste, along with clove cigarettes for an aftertaste.  Excellent.

Pours a hazy dark brown with a large off-white head and lots of carbonation.  Very yeasty, clove aroma with hints of wheat bread, citrus, banana, caramel, and plum.  Delicous flavors that start sweet and finish spicy.  There are all kinds of fruit flavors in the complex taste - raisin, banana, lemon, orange, prune, cherry.  This beer is full-bodied and excellently balanced, with a lively carbonation presence.  Very smooth going down and its not syrupy sweet, but rather crisp and refreshing.

From Halls in Colleyville, TX. Pours a dark brown with a fluffy tan head. Aroma of sweet dark fruits and a touch of caramel. Aromas just about perfect. Flavor of cloves, sweet dark fruit, caramel. Texture is very nice on the tongue. Nice beer.
user_location: Waco (Buckle of the Bible Belt), Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 27, 2005 Pours dark brown with a beige head. No lacings. Sweet and a light bitterness. Aromas of caramel malts, prunes, figs, clover and raisins. Medium to full bodied. Bitter finish with a bit of warming alcohol.

One pint, 0.9 oz (500 mL) brown bottle purchased from Warehouse Liquors, Chicago, IL  Hazy brown beer having small diminishing off-white head.   Nice aroma of spice (clove), toffee, and apricot.  Soft carbonation. Full bodied with a creamy oily texture that starts with smooth spicy, light sweet malt, toffee and smoke flavors.  Finishes dry with light clove and sweet malt aftertaste. Rich complex flavors and aroma. High gravity.  A fabulous wheat dopplebock, one of my favorite beers that I hope to enjoy over and over again.

Pours an amber orange color.  White head that stays afloat for a good while.  Aroma is definately wheaty.  You can always tell a wheat beer.  Touch of alcohol, estery.  Flavor is wheaty and kinda fruity.  Very decent beer, easy to drink, rich, full flavor.  Well done.
This beer pours a real dark amber color with a small htan head.  It has a roasty malted smell and a rich smokey malt flavor w/ a hint of chocolate that lingers. Cheers!

In the 0.5L bottle at the Huber Haus. Very intense beer. Strong clove aroma with a tough of smoke. Thick sweet fruit and wheat flavors. Big on esters. Serious alcohol, very chewy and filling. Just a great beer to look at with that merangue pie thick head.

deep ruby color, long lacing head. clove up front with a underlying banana hint. nice full body with crystal malt flavors, plums & typical wheat yeast strain undertones. a touch of chocolate but mosly clove, sweet finish. nice, well rounded taste.

(500 ml bottle) Cloudy brownish body, very large biege head. Aroma gluey. Spotty lacing. Tastes of alcoholic, malty sweetness along with the glue-like quality I associate with wheat beers. Smooth mouthfeel. Alcohol in this one will mellow you out. Not my favorite beer style but I appreciate its quality.
Bottle. White head. Dark red brown muddy body. Fruity malt aroma. Banana and cherry flavor.  Rather sweet.

Pour is deep brown with reddish hue and a lasting foam head. Nose is wheat notes of banana and predominantly clove. Mouthfeel is full and silky with minimal carbonation. Flavor is wheat then sweeter malt tones of plum and more clove. Extremely well balanced and enjoyable. One of the best widely-accesible German brews. Noch einmal.

This beer has a nice warm autumn-like red/brown colour. Its a lightly bitter doppelbock and its the best Ive had so far. Its an almost perfect creation. I cant wait to taste the Aventinus Eisbock...

Again, I am getting into the stronger wheats and this one is great. Beautiful dark cherry pour with a lasting white top. Toasty malt notes along with the banana and clove one would expect. Takes a hold of your mouth and wont let go! More subtle spices as it rests and warms. Me like.
(draft) Good, but not as good as everyone else seems to think. Nothing noteworthy at all. Id describe some details but there really arent any. Its just a beer.
50 cl bottle. Yeast in bottom. Aroma of yeast and wheat, hints of chocolate. Great flavour of wheat and yeast and hints of chocolate malt. Very tasteful and very drinkable.

50 cl bottel
Color - Dark REd/Brown
Head - Beige 
Aroma - Weat, yeast
Flavor - Weat, yeast
Good beer

Dont usually rate beers I can regularly get but this is such a classic, it deserves it!   Beautiful phenolic nose, creamy notes of clove and  bannana. Huge head that sticks around. Fine Champagne bubbles. Clear deep garnet in color. Rich, creamy and balanced, slight sweetness but not too cloying.  Alcohol is present but not overbearing.  I would use this as a session beer, exept for the 8% abv.

Aventinus, we need to talk...I dont think were working out well together.  Its not you...its me.  You are a pretty brew with your sparkling clear amber-brown color, and you KNOW I like the full body (wink) but I need more.  Your interesting smell of plumbs and pink grapefruit just doesnt do it for me.  Sorry.  The "clove-like" impression you claim is certainly true, but I just dont like cloves...it brings me back to my angry adolescence, sneaking away and smoking clove cigarettes (blah!).  Theres plenty of other raters out there that will appreciate you more than me...Im sure a quality brew such as yourself will be happier with them than with me.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2009 Dark reddish brown with a tan head.  A creamy long lasting head.  Smooth sweet palate with molasses.  The finish is nice, it melts away gradually.  Yeast, dough and cloves in the nose.   Score another for German brewers.

Rerate 12.29.09 just general impressions, this is brilliant.  The balance, the decadence, the hidden flavors and nuances.  One of the best I have ever had.
Nice almost smoky, subtle aroma.  Appearance is dark red/brown with a very white head.  Flavour is malty but also very yeasty.  Nice.  Full bodied is a good discription.
Cherry brown pour with some cloudiness.  The taste is sweet malt, some unfermented notes (kotikalja).  Relatively unpretentious and very drinkable.

Pours a deep amber/brown with a big tan head.  Nose is yeast, spices and, of course, wheat. Spiced flavors over a wheat base, malty notes beneath. Finish is a touch sticky, but not in a bad way. A true classic.

Aroma was mostly your normal German Hefe aromas - bready yeast, clove, banana, but this one was much more complex and had an alcoholic kick too.  Poured really pretty ruby brown with a 1/2" head.  Flavor was a very complex blend of malt sweetness, wheat, spice, and yeast.  Apparent alcoholic notes, but not overpowering.  Very tasty, lingering finish.  This is an excellent brew.

A murky deep red with a thick, creamy head reveals aromas of clove and spice. Yeast truly is a magical beast. The flavor follows with a tingle of carbonation, then a distinctive spicy, almost cherry-like flavor that is devoid of the thick, syrupy sweetnes that detracts from so many American beers of 8% alcohol. A great beer and a classic of this style.

An awesome non-session beer from one of my favorite brewers in the world, Georg.  This is not for the amateur beer drinker, but I think I have enough practice to handle it.  A gorgeous red wine of a beer with fruityness and darkness that mysteriously work together, an aroma that makes my nose smile, and deliciousness from start to finish.  Roll it from the front of your tongue to the back and its like a rainbow of awesomeness exploding in your mouth.  Bananas and caramel and yeastiness and delicious awesome combinations of complexity that my tongue is not sufficiently experienced to unentangle.  Awesome.  The antithesis of Anheuser World Select.

a VERY nice weizen Bock by Schneider. the first thing you notice when poring is the HUGE merange head that wants to jump out of the glass and halfway down it stays put!! nice aroma of sweet caramel and....raisins? a little whiff of peppery spice as well. I had smoked up some damn fine 3 and under ribs that this beer went wonderfully with. almost to well!!!!!

A Mes rate: 
Ok try as I might I cant help but admit this is damn fine stuff. Very very good aroma. Wheaty like a white beer, full on and fruity like a dubbel and something that is almost oud brune in there too. Appearance has just been upped to a 5 now that I have noticed how uneven the line between the body and head is. Its bumpy up and down and at each of the down points there is  a little spider trail of bubbles leading down into the body. There is no doubt this is a very very good looking beer. Flavour is chunky, balanced and complex. Dark AND light fruit, clove, yeast, caramel and pudding. Damn its all over the place! Its just very very slightly too sweet if you ask me but its hard to find fault. Mouthfeel is chunky, smooth and awesome. Just glorious all round really. This one has special memories for me too. Firstly because it finished Sim off big style at GBBF once and I had to LITERALLY carry her home. Secondly because there is a guy who drinks in the wonderful Bar Fringe in Manchester and only drinks Aventinus in the right glass that he keeps behind the bar.
