Definitely a fine brew though.
Strong, sweet, very good. Reminds us perhaps about some local brewed beers from western Norway..but thats unlikely, isnt it?

Truly enjoyed this one...sweet aroma but not too much.  Nice, creamy head and a very unique deep brown Im not used to seeing in a weissbier.  Flavors include plums, chocolate, cloves, maybe a little cinnamon.  Just a slight alcohol lingering, but of course rather high ABV.  This one quickly made my top 10, maybe even top 5.
UPDATED: MAR 19, 2005 Truly a classic.  Clove/banana wheatiness combined with the best of a doublebock.  Absolutely fabulous
The classic doppleback.  Im drinking one now.  Aint life grand!

Whoa nelly this is good stuff!  Sort of a best of when it comes to weizens and bocks.  Great yeasty and malty aroma with a pronounced hefe character (yeast, spices, minor citrus & hops) mingling with chocolate malt in the flavor profile.  Nice deep ruby to brown color with a rocky off-white head.  Very unique.
This stuff is just damn tasty. Hefe and doppelbock flavors intermingle in strange and wonderful ways. Tastes like candy says my wife, and she hated the Triple Bock. A winner all around.

One of the most coplex beers Ive had the pleasure of drinking. A doppelbock Weiss fullof great malt and chocolate flavor, also has a nice clove flavor.
A combination of the best things about  wheat beer and bock beer.
Very good Munich beer - kind of like Kasteel bier but without the alcohol taste.
I really cant get enough of this beer! Not sure youll agree, but Ill trade you 2 cases of Duvel for one of this!
Excellent doppelbock.  I havent tried many doppelbocks, so I dont knwo how this compares, but I liked it very much.
One of the best beers I have ever tasted, especially from a bottle.

I was really and pleasantly shocked when I had this wonderfull beer first time in one pub of Helsinki. Cant wait the moment when Ill find the opportunity to have it draught (although some of beerlovers think that bottled Aventinus is better). Anyway its the best dark wheat bock at all from my point of view!
Wow! Bananas are heavy in the aroma and then the cloves start. Have had this beer in both draft and bottle and the bottle is MUCH better. Some beers just dont translate well to draft.
A very good beer that makes a good comprimise between a wheat and something with a little more body to it. Very fresh, but I agree with the others in that there is a bit too much carbonation.
user_name: Almeter, The Aryan God of Beer

text: Brown to amber color, with a thick head. Personally I thought it was too fizzy, and the aftertaste was too sweet, but otherwise very pleasant. Nice robust, roasty flavor with fruit and spice undertones.

Delicious roasty, candy apple aroma.  Opaque with coffe-and-cream coloring.  I liked the full-bodied, malty, chocolate and banana flavor that resulted from the style mix, but I thought it was too bubbly.  Finishes with a sweet aftertaste, appropriately comprised of pears, plum, and prune undertones.

Sweet, fruity, spicy nose (could be stronger).  Barely translucent deep red/brown body with a great creamy head.  Flavor --huge -- doublebock/holiday spice beer flavors (cinnamon,apple,cloves) duke it out with weissbeer characteristics that seem to win out in the end.  An amazing beer, but not for every day; too much!

An intense, unique experience: the color a brown cloud, the head a billowing, persistent foam, the aroma and flavor deliciously pruney. Not for everyday imbibing; the very definition of a special-occasion beer.
Has the yeast flavour of a hefe-weizen, but the malty sweetness and strength of a doppelbock.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2003 An amazing looking beer--almost completely opaque with a solid, persistent head. Has an excellent flavor to go with it: slightly fruity, with hints of chocolate and a light bitterness to offset its sweetness. The alcohol flavor is somewhat strong: Aventinus packs something of a punch. Great stuff.

The example that I had was 8%, not 7.7% as stated above.  But that aside, it is a wonderfully thick and creamy beer.  This is the first wheat-doppel that I tried, and I am impressed with the hybrid.  The white head stayed with me until the end, contrasting greatly with the dark brown/black pigment of the beer itself.  I noticed a hint of the characteristic yeast flavor, but I think that the malty flavor of the doppel overpowered it.  Recommended

Now this is an excellent brew.  Great aroma, nice creamy head that lasts.  wonderful slightly bitter beginning with a semi sweet chocolaty palate.  The greatness of a dark beer and white beer all in  one.

World-classic; defines the Weizenbock/Weizenstarkbier style. Not for the faint of heart. Huge aroma, full of cloves, nutmeg, and fruit. Excellent phenolic/ester balance in flavor. Some sweetness in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2013 Re-rate (finally).  Poured from bottle.  Big aroma of apple pie, raisins, alcohol, and other dried fruits.  Downright scary lookin mahogany with a bit of head.  I taste all kinds of fruit - pear, plum, raisin, grape - along with caramel, wheat and smoke.  Surprisingly creamy feel with a slight bit of tangyness.  Delicious and quite well made.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Thick and luxuriant, yet acidic and crisp, with an amazing clove/raisin flavor. One of the greats.
UPDATED: MAR 12, 2003 rich juicy aroma with lots of fruit, apples, bananas, plums.  very sweet.   Mahagony color, head drops quickly.  Unbelivable finish.  sweet malts.  an excellent beer.
Slightly tart,  nicely malty.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2003 The beer pours a nebulous mahogany with orange highlights; the head is preposterous in size, the structure frothy, the color a medium tan. Nose is a tad yeasty, sweet malt, pleasing to the senses, start is ambrosial, and the top middling in feel. Finish has a crisp acidic bite, the hops subdued, the aftertaste dry and long lasting, a quite nice beer, as I have always been partial to the Bock family.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2008 Re-Rate 2-26-08
Pours a deep amber orange with a nice head of off white bubbles. Aromas of malt, clove, and soft banana. Clean malty slight-citrus flavor hits the tongue with a perfect amount of carbonation before giving way to caramel, banana, apricot, and hard candy. Then a clove like hop finish before going away leaving the palate awake and wanting more. World Class!
Not as full bodied as I would like, and a little sour, but not bad.
A very average beer.  Nothing terrible, but nothing outstanding.  Almost watery for a doppelbock.
Nothing stands out about this beer.  It has a mediocre aroma, mouthfeel and finish.  Even the head is mediocre

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2003 Dark reddish-brown, hazy, with big frothy head.  Luscious dark fruit aroma - banana, apple crumble, sweet malts, milk chocolate.  Most surprisingly is the hint of burning cedar - I've never picked that phenol out in Aventinus before (but then I haven't evaluated Aventinus in a while either); smooth dark malt palate...dark malts, sweet banana esters, liberal mix of alcohol.  Complex, stylish, and daring.  A great weizenbock.
UPDATED: OCT 21, 2003 ruby-brown colour, almost no foam, yeasty, haye and light banana aroma, sweet and sparkling, full-bodied, licorice and citrusy finish - a beautiful and powerfull beer

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2004 Deleting my previous rating of either a bad bottle or just a bad palate. The new rating is of Aventinus 2000 in 2003 New Years Eve.

Very cloudy brownish, with foaming large beige head, fading surprisingly rapidly. Banana and caramel are the first to be known in the nose, followed by mild phenols. Flavor is strongly sweet with true weizen flavors of banana, mild clove to give complexity. Mild melanoidin malts are present but are tempered by the phenols. Finish is light, refreshing, semi-dry, zesty, almost minty. A truly outstanding accomplishment in a beer so strong. Mild alcohol presence does come through, especially as the beer warms, but it's also amazing that a beer of this strength can retain its complexity and drinkability at cooler temps. Also amazing that this beer ages so well - it could perhaps survive a year or two more.
